'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-01-04 11:58:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Just thinking about the units used for counts.

whether we're counting images or disk I/O requests, seems to me the unit should just be something like 'count' (or even None) as opposed to 'image' or 'request'

(i.e the unit describes *how* the counter value should be interpreted, not *what* we're measuring ... e.g. in the disk.read.bytes counter, the unit just tells us that the measurement is in bytes, as opposed to 'bytes of disk I/O')

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-01-04 17:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-01-04 18:06:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

@eglynn - I thought about the units, too, but decided that "instance" was like "byte", since it says what is being counted. The "I/O read" aspect is captured in the meter name, so it doesn't need to be in the units.

I'm giving this +2, but not approving, pending consensus on this question.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-01-05 14:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

@gpernot

One issue inline to clear up.

@dhellmann

OK I'll soften my stance to a "-0" (once gpernot addresses the seconds versus nanoseconds issue), so as not to stand in the way of this patch.

Just for the record, the reason I think its a bit unnatural to use a unit of 'request' or 'image' say instead of count or None, is that the purpose of the unit IMO is mainly to reveal the scaling factor (e.g. bytes versus Kb or Mb).

Usually the quantity being measured is already revealed in the meter name, e.g. 'disk.read.bytes', but it's worth being slightly repetitious also specifying a unit of 'bytes', as there are other commonly used scaling factors for this quantity (Kb/Mb/Gb etc.). Similarly for say cpu time specified in nanoseconds, as opposed to seconds or minutes.

Whereas AFAIK there aren't any commonly used scaling factors for say images ... one doesn't talk so much about downloading 7 kilo-images in a day, or serving out 3.2 mega-images over the course of a week. Rather, we almost always count things like images and I/0 requests using a dimensionless natural number.

I also have a couple of more minor concerns, that we'll end up with needless unit proliferation, and also be inconsistent with other measuring systems such as AWS CloudWatch.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 186, 'date': '2013-01-05 15:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-05 16:05:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-01-07 13:14:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@eglynn - That makes a lot of sense, and I hadn't thought about it in those terms. Maybe a unit of "each" or "count" would be better. Should we discuss it on the mailing list, instead of through the tiny text boxes on the code-review tool? :-)'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-01-07 13:29:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

"Usually the quantity being measured is already revealed in the meter name, e.g. 'disk.read.bytes', but it's worth being slightly repetitious also specifying a unit of 'bytes', as there are other commonly used scaling factors for this quantity (Kb/Mb/Gb etc.). Similarly for say cpu time specified in nanoseconds, as opposed to seconds or minutes."

Nah nah. Let's think bigger, shall we.

Until now we put unit in counter names, but that's probably a bad habit. What about imagining a world where you can meter something like outgoing traffic with a name like network.outgoing and seeing it measured with 2 differents units: packets and bytes.

So you could retrieve the sum() in bytes or in packets via the API, and if you don't know the one you want, you could have both.

That means it's really better to not use a null value rather than image, IMHO, because you might end up with different units for the same counter.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2013-01-07 17:48:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@jd__

Sounds like a future use-case, but even, so I'm not sure there would be a problem with wildcarded aggregation as long as the individual meter names where returned along with the individual sums ... i.e. if I request the sum of image*, I could be returned \Sigma image.size with unit 'bytes' and \Sigma image.download with unit 'count'  etc. without there being any ambiguity.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-01-08 09:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-01-09 11:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I'll weight in with my 2c.

I think it's up to how you want this used:
1) is it a string-like "tag" that is bordering on free form
or 
2) it is very structured and managed (you have to patch ceilometer to use a new unit). - In which case we have
just "counter" and not instance/blocks/packets...

If it is "2" it makes consuming the data more reliable (there are only so many units and they are well defined).
"1" is more expressive but potentially is more difficult for
a user to consume (they have to parse the unit and figure out what to do with it).

snmp takes option "1": (grep for UNIT)
http://www.net-snmp.org/docs/mibs/UCD-SNMP-MIB.txt
Some examples:
UNITS       "blocks/s"
UNITS       "interrupts/s"
UNITS       "switches/s"
UNITS       "kB"
But they publish a mib and we don't.

I would argue that if we want option "1" we would 
need to publish counter definitions (like mibs) and/or
make the definitions more auto discoverable.

Taking option "2" is simpler. I like simple.

Thinking aloud, if it was very structured it would make
automatic cross unit calulations easier (5kb + 356b) or (4545 + 3.4k).


-A'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-01-10 19:29:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I just remembered that there's tools in bin/ and tin tools/ that uses Counter and that will be broken by this change."}, {'account_id': 186, 'date': '2013-01-11 13:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 186, 'date': '2013-01-11 13:10:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Provide the meters unit's in /meters

 * change pollsters and notification handlers to report units
 * modify db storage to store units in counters

Change-Id: Ibd7e52623b84d26ca7bbc9f260c20fdf1d61a4bc
Implements: blueprint provide-meter-units

commit_message:
Revert "shorten pep8 output"

Verbose PEP8 output is explicitly intended to make it easier for new contributors to propose acceptable patches.

This reverts commit 1f01d30983e3a67a146308ff8766f057bc5b7958

[{'created': '2013-01-11 14:43:43.000000000', 'message': "policy: fix policy_file finding

Currently, the policy.json file is only looked inside current directory.
Let's use cfg.config_dir via the find_file method to find the policy file.

Also add some unit test to catch theses errors.

This fixes bug #1098206

Change-Id: I896108f1bd66d3be6ec32b50d9dddc6c368f3709
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}]
commit_message:
policy: fix policy_file finding

Currently, the policy.json file is only looked inside current directory.
Let's use cfg.config_dir via the find_file method to find the policy file.

Also add some unit test to catch theses errors.

This fixes bug #1098206

Change-Id: I896108f1bd66d3be6ec32b50d9dddc6c368f3709
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-08 05:44:05.000000000', 'message': 'Fix test cases in integrated.test_multiprocess_api

Be patient in test_multiprocess_api while waiting service to be spawned or
killed, because:
    * Service spawning has a limit of one process a second.
    * A test server in the cloud might have limited resources,
      the time there might be several times slower.

Change-Id: If75e6dfa5d769985a6c1b46461f25485e2a996ad
'}, {'created': '2013-01-10 04:40:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix test cases in integrated.test_multiprocess_api

Fixes bug #1098043

Be patient in test_multiprocess_api while waiting service to be spawned or
killed, because:
    * Service spawning has a limit of one process a second.
    * A test server in the cloud might have limited resources,
      the time there might be several times slower.

Change-Id: If75e6dfa5d769985a6c1b46461f25485e2a996ad
'}]
commit_message:
Fix test cases in integrated.test_multiprocess_api

Fixes bug #1098043

Be patient in test_multiprocess_api while waiting service to be spawned or
killed, because:
    * Service spawning has a limit of one process a second.
    * A test server in the cloud might have limited resources,
      the time there might be several times slower.

Change-Id: If75e6dfa5d769985a6c1b46461f25485e2a996ad

commit_message:
Add sql_max_pool_size option

fixes bug 1087055

grizzly adds a new option to nova: sql_max_pool_size, which is
the max number of connections to keep open in a pool. This patch
adds it to the config reference section.

Patch 2 adds sql_max_overflow option and fixes a typo in the
previous commit

Patch 3
fixes bug 1087054
adds sql_min_pool_size and sql_dbpool_enable options

Change-Id: Id9d122e3002c2a91aaf83560f4bbff06911517f3

commit_message:
Backport Object Storage Admin Guide from trunk

Backport doc/src/docbkx/openstack-object-storage-admin/*

With small updates to bk-objectstorage-adminguide.xml metadata so
that it mentions Folsom instead of trunk.

Patchset updates pom.xml to 1.5.2, build works.

inline comments. I'm -2 on the patch for now, as this really needs to be broken up, and we really need to not be adding more db access calls into virt drivers. Inline comments explaining this in detail.

I think an incremental approach on this set of patches is really needed, as it would make it a lot easier to work on specific issues like not having enough info about the instance to do the volume attach, when code only related to that problem was in a single patch."}, {'account_id': 5149, 'date': '2012-11-27 23:45:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5149, 'date': '2012-11-27 23:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

About the blueprint vmware-compute-driver, I suggest you split the "huge" patch into several patches in order to make
the implementation easier to review. 
And furthermore, a huge patch may cause issues to the existing code. It is better to merge step by step. 
The blueprint includes items like Launch OVF disk image, VNC console,
Attach and Detach iSCSI volume, Guest info, Host ops, VLAN and Quantum integration, Cold migration and Live migration.
Perhaps we can have one patch for each of them. Within the commit message, The first paragraph can be Modifies the VMware compute driver.
The second paragraph could be the item to be implemented in this patch, e.g. Attach and Detach iSCSI volume with some more explanations.
And the third paragraph could be implements blueprint vmware-compute-driver.'}, {'account_id': 5149, 'date': '2012-12-14 22:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5149, 'date': '2012-12-14 22:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

. Host ops
. VLAN & Quantum integration

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-21 23:25:48.000000000', 'message': "A patch for an error which is thrown when the client runs keystone endpoint-list

When the python-keystoneclient (tested with version 0.2.1.2.g033cfe4) run
the command: keystone endpoint-list the server reports and error in its logs.
The error occues because it is assumed that the endpoint dictionary has
the key 'legacy_endpoint_id' in it and it does not always have this key.

Fixes bug #1093006

Change-Id: Ib4cd38d62f7edb2971daab1f9a4ccadf2533e779
"}]
commit_message:
A patch for an error which is thrown when the client runs keystone endpoint-list

When the python-keystoneclient (tested with version 0.2.1.2.g033cfe4) run
the command: keystone endpoint-list the server reports and error in its logs.
The error occues because it is assumed that the endpoint dictionary has
the key 'legacy_endpoint_id' in it and it does not always have this key.

Fixes bug #1093006

Change-Id: Ib4cd38d62f7edb2971daab1f9a4ccadf2533e779

I'm a little confused here. Are you saying that a nova api used to return an empty list data with a 2xx status, and now returns 4xx? Which api? Is there a nova bug about this change?"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-10 23:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

See this
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ec2-error-codes

I did not created a bug report for all error code mismatch.

The test case not fully correct anyway, it is not prepared for for very fast termination. I plan to enhance it in future commit.
In the other part of tempest we are waring for server delete nowadyas. I would wait here too.

If it return with an  empty list I need to check for ValueError as you can see in tear down functions. If it returns with error as sign of the resource successfully terminated/deleted  I need to accept it too if it conforms to EC2 specifications or reference implementation.

This test case never ran on a gate system, because the referenced devstack change not submitted . So we will not lose much if we disable it. It ran successfully on my sandbox when I submitted this case.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-01-10 23:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

OK, I guess the ec2 stuff was a little messed up. If this is really going to be a change in Grizzly then it will need to be in the release notes. I am not quite sure how that happens but will try to find out.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-11 13:33:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Disable test_run_terminate_instance

Looks like the nova API now gives an error response instead of an
empty list. It can be a correct behaviort, but it does it with an incorrect
error code.

This change let us pass on the https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19098/
change and continue the work on tempest and nova side.

Change-Id: I18309429e9967ccd7804ff0cc1c385ece100dd67

[{'created': '2013-01-09 18:32:14.000000000', 'message': "Add wait for resource deletion on volume teardown

The teardown routines in some of the tests were not
waiting for verification that the volume was actually deleted.
As a result it's easy to intermittently hit a case where we run
out of space for volume create in the following tests.

This patch just adds a resource_deletion check/wait after
each volume delete operation to make sure we don't get ahead
of ourselves.

Change-Id: I47f9ad2b8e6f79348c3d6188da3c24af0c6fe5d4
Fixes: bug 1092689
"}]
commit_message:
Add wait for resource deletion on volume teardown

The teardown routines in some of the tests were not
waiting for verification that the volume was actually deleted.
As a result it's easy to intermittently hit a case where we run
out of space for volume create in the following tests.

This patch just adds a resource_deletion check/wait after
each volume delete operation to make sure we don't get ahead
of ourselves.

Change-Id: I47f9ad2b8e6f79348c3d6188da3c24af0c6fe5d4
Fixes: bug 1092689

'}, {'account_id': 2463, 'date': '2012-12-20 08:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for picking this up! Rather than adding just a single "Highly available OpenStack services" sections, could you please split them up by service, i.e. Glance, Keystone etc. I realize this will make them fairly short stubs for now, but the structure would be right for future expansion.'}, {'account_id': 2585, 'date': '2012-12-20 10:57:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The group won't work.

g_openstack p_vip_openstack p_keystone p_glance_registry p_glance_api

Keystone should start right away after the VIP, if it doesn't monitor functions from glance service will crash since they can't retrieve any token. This may be negligible I guess, because monitor function doesn't start immediately but I'll prefer to see keystone start first :-).

I don't know which RA you use for glance-registry but the option os_auth_url doesn't exist anymore. The RA doesn't need it, it's client side. The RA only needs the keystone token url and the images api url."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

After discussion with Florian :

commit_message:
policy: fix policy_file finding

Currently, the policy.json file is only looked inside current directory.
Let's use cfg.config_dir via the find_file method to find the policy file.

Also add some unit test to catch theses errors.

This fixes bug #1098206

Change-Id: I896108f1bd66d3be6ec32b50d9dddc6c368f3709
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Add test cases that actually serve http requests

* test_app starts wsgi.Service with a test app, then creates
  a url to make sure the http requests are actually served
  properly

* test_app_using_router adds wsgi.Router and Mapper() to the
  mix along with using the wsgify annotation for serving
  the http requests

Change-Id: I612ad4f3d6a72cf47948f9285d7183ec55ad96f0

Enable wsgi.Service to listen on ipv6 address

Check if the host specified is ipv6. Based on that
set the appropriate family in the eventlet.listen api

Added a test case

This adds an extras.d directory to contain startup scripts that
stack.sh runs automatically at the end.  Similar to local.sh
except the scripts are sourced into the stack.sh process rather
than executed as a child process.  This gives them complete

commit_message:
Add mechanism to automatically load additional projects

This adds an extras.d directory to contain startup scripts that
stack.sh runs automatically at the end.  Similar to local.sh
except the scripts are sourced into the stack.sh process rather
than executed as a child process.  This gives them complete
access to the stack.sh environment.

Convert Tempest to use this format as an example.

Change-Id: Ibc95e6aaecf4211da948319eb452293ae4357780

[{'created': '2013-01-11 11:48:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystoneclient auth_token middleware changes

Things changed, and the configuration wasn't read anymore. This patch fixes
that. It also remove duplicated code in acl.py, so the problem is fixed only
in one place. Finally, it uses prepare_service() to find the right
configuration file for ceilometer.

This fixes bug #1098204

Change-Id: I0d6c30ad443a4d0db201e60d12b275625a4bee6e
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystoneclient auth_token middleware changes

Things changed, and the configuration wasn't read anymore. This patch fixes
that. It also remove duplicated code in acl.py, so the problem is fixed only
in one place. Finally, it uses prepare_service() to find the right
configuration file for ceilometer.

This fixes bug #1098204

Change-Id: I0d6c30ad443a4d0db201e60d12b275625a4bee6e
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Add missing methods to xml admin_client.

This adds methods missing from the xml version of the identity
admin client. These methods are needed by some of the tests in
test_list_server_filters.

Partially fixes bug 1059568

Change-Id: Iec0fd7ff49de78b9681ccfa27963393aff248b5f

commit_message:
Fix keystoneclient auth_token middleware changes

Things changed, and the configuration wasn't read anymore. This patch fixes
that. It also remove duplicated code in acl.py, so the problem is fixed only
in one place. Finally, it uses prepare_service() to find the right
configuration file for ceilometer.

This fixes bug #1098204

Change-Id: I0d6c30ad443a4d0db201e60d12b275625a4bee6e
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

Currently 'add_nova_opt' simply appends options to the nova.conf
file. This doesn't work if the file contains multiple groups.
Until oslo provides a tool to handle updating config files, create
a local dumb tool for such purposes

Change-Id: Id520b584a6727910e6f57786fb40c546080f094a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make it possible to set nova option groups

Currently 'add_nova_opt' simply appends options to the nova.conf
file. This doesn't work if the file contains multiple groups.
Until oslo provides a tool to handle updating config files, create
a local dumb tool for such purposes

Change-Id: Id520b584a6727910e6f57786fb40c546080f094a
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Check the display name for volumes on AJAX polls.

If a volume is created from the CLI without a name,
its displayed name on the Dashboard will be its id.

Change-Id: I806df643d7a2e0e93db673ea9718fe30927d930e
Implements: Display name check for unnamed volumes
Fixes: bug #1070042

commit_message:
Remove bogus 'unplug' calls from libvirt VIF test

Since the 'get_config' method was introduced to the libvirt
VIF class, separate from the 'plug' method, there is no need
to call the 'unplug' method in the test suite

Blueprint: libvirt-vif-driver
Change-Id: I1c3d055e258117c2657cd72386472dff2e0e08b8
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Fix libvirt resume function call to get_domain_xml

commit_message:
added project_id to add and remove fixed ip calls

If an admin is adding or removing fixed ips from an
instance, the context will not contain the instance's
project_id. Other services which key off of this
will not work correctly unless we pass the instance's
project_id in discretely from context.

Change-Id: I3a886e6cc0d77b662f0ea80e10040c26387fc53f

commit_message:
Create a directory for servicegroup drivers.

Right now there is only one servicegroup driver, the db backed driver.
Create a directory for drivers to reside in to keep things a bit more
tidy as we add additional drivers.

Part of blueprint rpc-based-servicegroup-driver.

Change-Id: Ib563e1a8d184cef838e5730b2fc6904940d04c21

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 10:02:38.000000000', 'message': "Move logic from os-api-host into compute

Renames host to host_name in various places to make it more explicit
what it is the api's are accepting and what we are passing around.

Moves logic out of the openstack api's host extension into the compute
library. This is in preparation for cells; cells provides its own
compute library that proxy's certain calls to child cells.

In an effort to separate out the layers of code, we're moving all DB
related logic out of the openstack api layer and into the compute
library layer.

For example @check_host which calls the DB should not be in the
openstack api layer. In the case of cells, we can't check the host until
we arrive at the cell that contains the host.

Implements: blueprint host-api-prep-for-cells
Change-Id: Icb861fd323ba707ab3b661f0a2c6d8bb7bfdc85e
"}, {'created': '2013-01-07 12:32:13.000000000', 'message': "Move logic from os-api-host into compute

Renames host to host_name in various places to make it explicit what it
is the api's are accepting and what we are passing around.

Moves logic out of the openstack api's host extension the compute
library. This is in preparation for cells; cells provides its own
compute library that proxy's certain calls to child cells.

In an effort to separate out the layers of code, we're moving all DB
related logic out of the openstack api layer and into compute library
layer.

For example @check_host which calls the DB should not be he openstack
api layer. In the case of cells, we can't check for the existence of the
host until we arrive at the cell that contains the host.

Implements: blueprint host-api-prep-for-cells
Change-Id: Icb861fd323ba707ab3b661f0a2c6d8bb7bfdc85e
"}, {'created': '2013-01-07 19:30:18.000000000', 'message': "Move logic from os-api-host into compute

is the api's are accepting and what we are passing around.

Moves logic out of the openstack api's host extension the compute
library. This is in preparation for cells; cells provides its own
compute library that proxy's certain calls to child cells.

In an effort to separate out the layers of code, we're moving all DB
related logic out of the openstack api layer and into compute library

commit_message:
Move logic from os-api-host into compute

Renames host to host_name in various places to make it explicit what it
is the APIs are accepting and what we are passing around.

Moves logic out of the openstack api's host extension to the compute
library. This is in preparation for cells; cells provides its own
compute library that proxies certain calls to child cells.

In an effort to separate out the layers of code, we're moving all DB
related logic out of the openstack api layer and into compute library
layer.

For example @check_host which calls the DB should not be in the openstack
api layer. In the case of cells, we can't check for the existence of the
host until we arrive at the cell that contains the host.

Implements: blueprint host-api-prep-for-cells
Change-Id: Icb861fd323ba707ab3b661f0a2c6d8bb7bfdc85e

commit_message:
Access instance as dict, not object in xenapi

get_all_bw_counters() in XenAPI was accessing instances as objects
instead of dicts.

Fixes bug 1098382

Change-Id: I9a783c0f403b60d392dc26a25b93683e7c145600

commit_message:
Update common openstack code from oslo-incubator

* Update to oslo-incubator commit b17b268a269c4989d76267db5c2d49d4c20bd51d.
* Update usage of 'deferred_version_string' to 'cached_version_string'
* Add context values 'user' and 'tenant' for context-logging
* Remove prefixes that resolve to '%prog' in --version CLI output

Change-Id: I24d9a24ad1a6e9379008ea719c9cbd22899111f9

commit_message:
Fix iniset and his friends

* In python the white spaces are part of the section name
* Handle options with empty value
* Support paths with white spaces

Change-Id: I69a584608853cfdb8b7dce1e24d929216ef2fc41

commit_message:
Move update_instance_info_cache to conductor.

The network API always updates the instance_info_caches table whenever
someone asks for current network information for an instance.  When
the compute manager calls network_api.get_instance_nw_info(), we'll need
to use the conductor for the cache update instead of a local DB call.

Adds an option to network_api's get_instance_nw_info() to not update the
cache and adds code into compute manager to update the cache via the
conductor.

Related to blueprint no-db-compute-manager

Change-Id: I36c3eb5b4e31ef2e26d3023bf2521d95205eb6ac

[{'created': '2013-01-10 21:36:08.000000000', 'message': "Change ComputerDriver.legacy_nwinfo to raise by default.

This makes non-updated hypervisors visible by grepping for 'def
legacy_nwinfo' rather than only the updated ones being visible, and
when new hypervisors are added, it will be clear whether they use the
legacy format or not.

Out of tree hypervisors will be broken by this, but the fix is
trivial::

def legacy_nwinfo(self):
    # XXX TODO Update to use the non-legacy format.
    return True

Change-Id: If5b461bc5d8e8dc21de3ca9cf521e7b341724900
"}]
commit_message:
Change ComputerDriver.legacy_nwinfo to raise by default.

This makes non-updated hypervisors visible by grepping for 'def
legacy_nwinfo' rather than only the updated ones being visible, and
when new hypervisors are added, it will be clear whether they use the
legacy format or not.

Out of tree hypervisors will be broken by this, but the fix is
trivial::

def legacy_nwinfo(self):
    # XXX TODO Update to use the non-legacy format.
    return True

Change-Id: If5b461bc5d8e8dc21de3ca9cf521e7b341724900

commit_message:
Add EXTRA_BAREMETAL_OPTS to stack.sh

Allow the passing of extra options to the [baremetal] option group
by specifying EXTRA_BAREMETAL_OPTS, using the same format as the
existing flag EXTRA_OPTS.

Change-Id: I209675786c6a33a68d83a371292a1e1749ecb14c

commit_message:
Fix tempest flavors and DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE

The flavor selection was broken if DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE is defined
but not yet created, for example when it is created in local.sh.
This also has the side effect of setting flavor_ref_alt to the first
flavor where it was unset in the previous code.

Change-Id: I1fa48b3f90af45144c92298b6b07a4f7ee3b499f

commit_message:
Update instance's cell_name in API cell.

It was accidentally being removed before updating the DB due to code
being moved and not updated.  The test for the method was broken, too,
allowing this bug to sneak in.

Fixes bug 1098093

Change-Id: I05c00b8b100568b39afb8ee0ca7ee94d4dd97c0a

commit_message:
Add user/tenant shim to RequestContext

This is necessary because we pass the Nova context object to
openstack-common/code (logging, for example), which expects the
attributes to be named user/tenant not user_id/project_id.

Fixes bug 1098278

Change-Id: Ic0dc49ef54515fc0ffaa0895cf4d88701afb1e16
(cherry picked from commit ce098ccce9d67df8c243fa885640989a4703ac53)

Ah.  I hit this yesterday, also.  I ended up modifying the default log strings as I thought it was a side effect of testing with no-auth.

I'm cool with this for now.  The shim should probably be the opposite... Ie, have a project_id and user_id shim. :)   and I guess base nova's RequestContext off of the one in openstack-common.   But... we can do this later.

commit_message:
add note about swift-init --kill-wait N

fixes bug 1095509

Adds a note about this new-to-grizzly parameter in swift-init
that is helpful in slow systems to ensure they don't kill
processes too early.

Change-Id: I76b159a6d8a54ad1085fb72cf4e7b6e34aa47440

commit_message:
fix int-tests running with out volume

fixed up the instance create and user/database level tests
fixed up the resize up test
fixed up and able to run through the entire suite of tests
fixed issues with the guest not writing the my.cnf file correctly

Fixes Bug #1095929

Change-Id: I2f971a072728380f83d82fdcb7595604a78a0511

except adding a config_true_value function this patch does not seem to implement the SWIFTCLIENT_INSECURE feature."}, {'account_id': 4234, 'date': '2013-01-09 02:41:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi

Thank you for your review and comment.

I checked my patch. But I guess env[SWIFTCLIENT_INSECURE] feature is implemented as follows.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18458/1/bin/swift

In this code, I use config_true_value function.

I am sorry if I misunderstand your comment.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-09 10:24:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi you, apologies if I misunderstand you but I could not see where is the feature implemented, you are adding a env variable and a switch but for what?'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-09 10:32:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Oh apologies I read the commit message differently and I thought you were trying to add that feature but it was already there.

I think it would be nicer to move the config_true_value to its own file as for example utils.py and you probably want to remove client.py:254 and just use insecure=kwargs.get('insecure') later on.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 4234, 'date': '2013-01-10 04:24:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your advice.
I will fix and submit the patch again.'}, {'account_id': 4234, 'date': '2013-01-10 04:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-10 04:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

If set to 'true', allow to access insecure keystone server.

commit_message:
Add env[SWIFTCLIENT_INSECURE]

Add env[SWIFTCLIENT_INSECURE] as default of --insecure option.
If set to 'true', allow to access insecure keystone server.
The name follows 'NOVACLIENT_INSECURE' in novaclient.

Change-Id: I322674eba9c07e6def97bce339815fa15191a92d

commit_message:
fix new N402 errors

fix the N402 errors that have slipped in in the last 48 hrs since
starting this patch series.

fix an N401 error that our scanner current can't find because it
only looks for doc strings on classes and defs.

this is the xeno's paradox of patch series, but we're getting close.

Change-Id: I4a763bb4c812335d853eae05c72464f18ab93297

commit_message:
Correct comment about SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE.

The comment regarding SWIFT_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE in lib/swift used the
incorrect unit (bytes instead of kilobytes).

Change-Id: I86117e36141c0a028a6fa6878a4d540f624e759d

commit_message:
Update instance's cell_name in API cell.

It was accidentally being removed before updating the DB due to code
being moved and not updated.  The test for the method was broken, too,
allowing this bug to sneak in.

Fixes bug 1098093

Change-Id: I05c00b8b100568b39afb8ee0ca7ee94d4dd97c0a
(cherry picked from commit abc9a0d5df70ee00ba38e655a4d88ae18417f0e3)

commit_message:
Fix tempest variable dependencies for quantum.

 * Ensure that quantum environment variables are properly
   referenced as dependencies in lib/tempest.
 * Move Q_ROUTER_NAME to stackrc since it is referenced by
   both lib/quantum and lib/tempest.

Change-Id: Ib58934c1f011604bf6f01dbf11b014ebd72f17df

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-10 17:21:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix init_host checking moved instances

Commit 6fc00d3465185 (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18486/)
introduced a couple of problems.

1) It introduced a method to try to deduce instance integer id from
   a name the driver reports and using instance_name_template.  This
   fails badly when you're using something like 'instance-%(uuid)s' for
   instance_name_template.  It's only used when the driver does not
   support the 'list_instance_uuids' method.. but XenAPI happens to
   not implement this method.

2) There's a call to _get_instance_volume_block_device_info() that is
   passing an instance_uuid when the method wants an instance.

Fixes bug 1097987 (#1 above) by doing a brute force match against
   all instances' names.
Fixes bug 1097978 (#2 above)

Change-Id: I2da7658dd906fa06f0e867a2b22bf14e7f34cb12
(cherry picked from commit d25991b41b5f476c293a6cf62361b115a160c64a)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix init_host checking moved instances

Commit 6fc00d3465185 (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18486/)
introduced a couple of problems.

1) It introduced a method to try to deduce instance integer id from
   a name the driver reports and using instance_name_template.  This
   fails badly when you're using something like 'instance-%(uuid)s' for
   instance_name_template.  It's only used when the driver does not
   support the 'list_instance_uuids' method.. but XenAPI happens to
   not implement this method.

2) There's a call to _get_instance_volume_block_device_info() that is
   passing an instance_uuid when the method wants an instance.

Fixes bug 1097987 (#1 above) by doing a brute force match against
   all instances' names.
Fixes bug 1097978 (#2 above)

Change-Id: I2da7658dd906fa06f0e867a2b22bf14e7f34cb12
(cherry picked from commit d25991b41b5f476c293a6cf62361b115a160c64a)

[{'created': '2013-01-09 18:31:55.000000000', 'message': "Sleep to give logs a chance to be flushed.

The Jenkins SCP plugin copies log files that have been copied by
devstack-gate from their normal locations to the log directory for that
particular test run. Sometimes these SCP'ed files are showing up
incomplete and that appears to be happening because the services are
unable to flush their log buffers before copying happens. Sleep for two
seconds before copying the logs to give the log buffers a chance at
flushing.

Change-Id: I12307a2f93839015e83389da8f6a10549044bd81
"}]
commit_message:
Sleep to give logs a chance to be flushed.

The Jenkins SCP plugin copies log files that have been copied by
devstack-gate from their normal locations to the log directory for that
particular test run. Sometimes these SCP'ed files are showing up
incomplete and that appears to be happening because the services are
unable to flush their log buffers before copying happens. Sleep for two
seconds before copying the logs to give the log buffers a chance at
flushing.

Change-Id: I12307a2f93839015e83389da8f6a10549044bd81

[{'created': '2013-01-10 00:32:07.000000000', 'message': 'Set content-length despite webob

Webob has a tendency to wipe out the content-length we set on responses.
This causes eventlet to use chunked transfer encoding. By changing the
order of operations, however, we can trigger eventlet to use the simpler
and more informative Content-Length header.

Change-Id: I0ed27c9e668a538bc0fc29cb6e9127dfb7fd8c78
'}]
commit_message:
Set content-length despite webob

Webob has a tendency to wipe out the content-length we set on responses.
This causes eventlet to use chunked transfer encoding. By changing the
order of operations, however, we can trigger eventlet to use the simpler
and more informative Content-Length header.

Change-Id: I0ed27c9e668a538bc0fc29cb6e9127dfb7fd8c78

Fixes bug 1097978 (#2 above)

Change-Id: I2da7658dd906fa06f0e867a2b22bf14e7f34cb12
"}, {'created': '2013-01-10 08:17:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix init_host checking moved instances

Commit 6fc00d3465185 (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18486/)
introduced a couple of problems.

1) It introduced a method to try to deduce instance integer id from
   a name the driver reports and using instance_name_template.  This
   fails badly when you're using something like 'instance-%(uuid)s' for
   instance_name_template.  It's only used when the driver does not
   support the 'list_instance_uuids' method.. but XenAPI happens to
   not implement this method.

2) There's a call to _get_instance_volume_block_device_info() that is
   passing an instance_uuid when the method wants an instance.

Fixes bug 1097987 (#1 above) by doing a brute force match against
   all instances' names.
Fixes bug 1097978 (#2 above)

Change-Id: I2da7658dd906fa06f0e867a2b22bf14e7f34cb12
"}]
commit_message:
Fix init_host checking moved instances

Commit 6fc00d3465185 (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/18486/)
introduced a couple of problems.

1) It introduced a method to try to deduce instance integer id from
   a name the driver reports and using instance_name_template.  This
   fails badly when you're using something like 'instance-%(uuid)s' for
   instance_name_template.  It's only used when the driver does not
   support the 'list_instance_uuids' method.. but XenAPI happens to
   not implement this method.

2) There's a call to _get_instance_volume_block_device_info() that is
   passing an instance_uuid when the method wants an instance.

Fixes bug 1097987 (#1 above) by doing a brute force match against
   all instances' names.
Fixes bug 1097978 (#2 above)

Change-Id: I2da7658dd906fa06f0e867a2b22bf14e7f34cb12

commit_message:
Fix debug feature and add --debug to swift.

- Remove PYTHON_SWIFTCLIENT and use --debug making it more consistents
  with other openstack clients libraries.
- Fix printing the curl command.
- Don't show the body of the GET objects it could get bad on large
  objects and it's an iterator anyway.
- Use -I for showing HEADs (and not -X HEAD).

Change-Id: I954e7d3d795401fc3679725440dec36cdc80af87

commit_message:
rename port attribute variable to SECURITYGROUPS from SECURITYGROUP

This patch renames the port attribute variable to the plural form since
multiple security groups can be associated with a port. This patch does
not change the security groups api and also does not change the
configuration section name to be SECURITYGROUPS.
Fixes bug 1095885

Change-Id: I1a4df337b48da0ef9c94d74b04c0b86333ce2f0c

commit_message:
ensure we wait for server deletes

we've got another place where ci has been flakey because we aren't
waiting for server deletes, fix that.

At the same time remove a sleep 60 which isn't needed any more.

This class is also ripe to try to move server setup into class setup
instead of test setup.

Change-Id: Ic7ea69c88804e380015faf50e4172d29611a1e8f

commit_message:
fix dependencies

- remove unneeded webob dependency
- add latest nova folsom release
- lock versions to those in the nova folsom release

Change-Id: Idb41535d932f094274e8e36ed8634b1553f3b1a0

[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2013-01-09 12:57:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> - We're creating a global pound symbol shortage

lol

This is _much_ better.
The wrapping is a bit awkward as it triggers often
with the appended "(integer value)" etc.
I'd increase the wrapping value slightly to a/c for that.
Also I'd s/ value// as it's redundant and
exacerbates the wrapping problem.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-09 13:00:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Since this is auto-generated, can we just avoid storing nova.conf.sample in GIT altogether. Make setup.py run the generator at build time.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-09 13:14:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Try out a new nova.conf.sample format

The current format strikes me as fairly bizarre:

  - Having the help message after the option it's documenting seems
    backwards to me. Compare to the glance or swift samples.

  - Printing the type as e.g. "(StrOpt)" isn't very user friendly

  - We're creating a global pound symbol shortage

Switch to a new format that looks much more like a normal config file.

Change-Id: Ifba0a181667f3b81cad400f1cdd3812e388a9d64

commit_message:
Update gitignore because of oslo setup.py

Change I6ed3a97e35ce73b820f7a436214480051ed6528f started using
setup.py in oslo. This adds support for auto generating the AUTHORS
and ChangeLog files.

This adds these files to gitignore and adds a .mailmap to cleanup the file.

Fixes bug 979958.

Change-Id: If61920c81499c5e579d3c1e7a66f8bf02020dfa9

'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-08 16:25:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Nice work.

1 nit: I think that you should check for the full return code not just a 2XX response."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-08 16:42:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I do not do it bacause:
* The rest of the code does not do it, it is out of the scope of this change.
* On reviews you can see someone claims all 2xx are OK.'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-01-08 17:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There has been some controversy about this but the consensus of the Core tempest team has been that return codes for APIs are part of the spec. In this case it is 204 as stated in

http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-identity-service/2.0/content/DELETE_deleteTenant_v2.0_tenants__tenantId__Admin_API_Service_Developer_Operations-d1e1356.html'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-08 17:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It is a listing. What is the code for listing ?'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-01-08 18:17:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry, I was confused by the unified diff. There is a comment on the tenants doc page that list_tenants is missing. The return values for keystone don't seem to be so well specified.
Some say they could return 200 or 203.  I'm OK with punting on this and accepting 2xx."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-01-08 18:20:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Note also that these identity tests will have to be massively changed to support v3:

https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/openstack-identity-api/src/markdown/identity-api-v3.md

The new version of this (list-projects) returns 200 :)'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-08 22:45:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

ok, changing to a +1, I couldn't find a clear definition on it anywhere either."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-01-09 16:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Fix tenant leaking in test_tenants.py

* listing test removed, because the delete test contained similar logic
* negative tests are marked as negativ

Fixes Bug: #1080971

Change-Id: I9a602b02be65ada92df1c8c967aeae728f2ca5f7

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-01-09 17:19:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's worth pointing out that eventlet does not support IPv6 at present.  That said, most of the difficulty has to do with eventlet's version of the address resolution routines; I believe using the raw IPv6 addresses works OK, as long as you can keep eventlet from trying to pipe them through name service resolution.

FYI, I have seen where IPv6 is a development priority for eventlet for 2013, but the support isn't there yet."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-09 17:22:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-09 18:52:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin,

Yes, i'd like to build up the ipv6 support using raw addresses  and get to a point where we only need the eventlet changes to wrap up.

thanks,
dims"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-01-09 19:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Enhance wsgi to listen on ipv6 address

* Check if the hostname is ipv6 and set the family appropriately
* Add test case for wsgi.Server and service.WSGIService

Change-Id: I6edd467467fa3d623d62e146750b3a6c42d8833c

commit_message:
Create signing_dir for ceilometer.

Create and initialize the signing_dir for ceilometer keystone
authentication. This ensures the ceilometer to use its own PKI cache
directory for authentication and avoids the authentication error due to
the invalid cached certifications.

Change-Id: I6fbc364695ae9be800245d14fd8945d531679550

commit_message:
Support separate replication ip address.

- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication processe uses new function now.

Change-Id: I5a8bad88f98b3740b7f594dae5ed3a2d17906874
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

commit_message:
Remove unused baremetal PXE options

These options were introduced by commit a2f260f and appear to never to
have been used.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-10 03:23:18.000000000', 'message': "Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are similar to the counterpart in Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_volume_stats() method of iSCSIDriver as an example to
demonstrate how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- port common filters/weights from oslo
- add capacity weigher (scheduler/weights/capacity.py) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing free capacity of the host. The default
behavior is to spread volumes across hosts; by changing the
'capacity_weight_multiplier' to negative number, volume placing behavior will
become stacking.
- add capacity filter which filters those hosts have insufficient storage space
to serve the request.
- add 'reserved_percentage' config option to indicate how much space is
reserved. Capacity reservation is needed when volume resize is enabled.
- add 'publish_service_capabilities()' method to volume RPC API to allow
scheduler to have volume service report capabilities. This bumps volume RPC
API to version 1.2
- remove 'volume_force_update_capabilities' config option, volume status will be
report to scheduler in every checking.

The implication of this change to storage/backend driver developer:
- implementation of get_volume_stats() of the driver is now a *MUST*, filter
scheduler heavily relies on the status/capabilities reported by backend driver
to makeplacement decision.  To ensure Cinder works seamlessly on the storage
system, driver should at least report following capabilities/status:
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  Capability/Status   |      Description          |         Example
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
 'volume_backend_name'| back-end name, string     | 'Example_Storage_Backend'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'vendor_name'       | vendor name, string       | 'OpenStackCinder'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'driver_version'    | version, string           |  '1.0a'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_protocol'  | supported protocols,      | 'iSCSI', 'RBD', 'FC', 'NFS'
                      | string or list of strings | ['iSCSI', 'NFS', 'FC']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'total_capacity_gb' | capacity in GB, integer   |  102400
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'free_capacity_gb'  | available capacity in GB, |  1000
                      | integer                   |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
'reserved_percentage' | reserved space in         |  0, 10
                      | percentage, integer       |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------

The implication of this change to Cinder administrator:
- the default setting for filter scheduler should work well with the benefits
of:
  * being able to fully utilize capacity of backends (driver now has to report
  actul total space and space utilization and scheduler uses these info) not
  limited by the 'max_gigabytes' config option any more;
  * being able to choose placement policy between spreading & stacking for
  volume creation (by modifying the 'capacity_weight_multiplier' in
  CapacityWeigher)
- with filter scheduler, Cinder is now able to utilize the advanced features/
capabilities provided by different storage back-ends via: defining different
volume types with proper extra_specs. Volume types can be considered as sets
of back-end capabilities requirement.
 For example, a volume type which has 'storage_protocol':'FC' key/value pair
definition in its extra_spec can only be served by those back-ends who report
they support FiberChannel protocol. Another example is volume type has 'QoS'
requirement can only be served by back-ends support QoS.

Note/TODO:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. More sophisticated way may be add on table in DB to
record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I296b3727db8de0d4cf085fac602d122a7b474842
"}]
commit_message:
Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are similar to the counterpart in Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_volume_stats() method of iSCSIDriver as an example to
demonstrate how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- port common filters/weights from oslo
- add capacity weigher (scheduler/weights/capacity.py) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing free capacity of the host. The default
behavior is to spread volumes across hosts; by changing the
'capacity_weight_multiplier' to negative number, volume placing behavior will
become stacking.
- add capacity filter which filters those hosts have insufficient storage space
to serve the request.
- add 'reserved_percentage' config option to indicate how much space is
reserved. Capacity reservation is needed when volume resize is enabled.
- add 'publish_service_capabilities()' method to volume RPC API to allow
scheduler to have volume service report capabilities. This bumps volume RPC
API to version 1.2
- remove 'volume_force_update_capabilities' config option, volume status will be
report to scheduler in every checking.

The implication of this change to storage/backend driver developer:
- implementation of get_volume_stats() of the driver is now a *MUST*, filter
scheduler heavily relies on the status/capabilities reported by backend driver
to makeplacement decision.  To ensure Cinder works seamlessly on the storage
system, driver should at least report following capabilities/status:
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  Capability/Status   |      Description          |         Example
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
 'volume_backend_name'| back-end name, string     | 'Example_Storage_Backend'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'vendor_name'       | vendor name, string       | 'OpenStackCinder'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'driver_version'    | version, string           |  '1.0a'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_protocol'  | supported protocols,      | 'iSCSI', 'RBD', 'FC', 'NFS'
                      | string or list of strings | ['iSCSI', 'NFS', 'FC']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'total_capacity_gb' | capacity in GB, integer   |  102400
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'free_capacity_gb'  | available capacity in GB, |  1000
                      | integer                   |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
'reserved_percentage' | reserved space in         |  0, 10
                      | percentage, integer       |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------

The implication of this change to Cinder administrator:
- the default setting for filter scheduler should work well with the benefits
of:
  * being able to fully utilize capacity of backends (driver now has to report
  actul total space and space utilization and scheduler uses these info) not
  limited by the 'max_gigabytes' config option any more;
  * being able to choose placement policy between spreading & stacking for
  volume creation (by modifying the 'capacity_weight_multiplier' in
  CapacityWeigher)
- with filter scheduler, Cinder is now able to utilize the advanced features/
capabilities provided by different storage back-ends via: defining different
volume types with proper extra_specs. Volume types can be considered as sets
of back-end capabilities requirement.
 For example, a volume type which has 'storage_protocol':'FC' key/value pair
definition in its extra_spec can only be served by those back-ends who report
they support FiberChannel protocol. Another example is volume type has 'QoS'
requirement can only be served by back-ends support QoS.

Note/TODO:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. More sophisticated way may be add on table in DB to
record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I296b3727db8de0d4cf085fac602d122a7b474842

commit_message:
Use real capabilites for volume type instead of fake ones

Replace fake capabilities requirements in volume type extra spec
with real capabilites that Cinder/iSCSI driver would report.

fix bug: 1098017

Change-Id: I0e226c14df95097cfdf653f0a13a45b8acff39da

commit_message:
Align common setup with the rest of OpenStack.

Use the common version code as well, and make setup.py consume it.

Change-Id: Ia1bfd8dad970e8674ebedb84b35eb7ba7a770d4e

@Arata, 

a discussion arose this morning as to whether deploy kernel/ramdisk should be properties of images or flavors, and what this affects in a multi-arch or multi-tenant deployment. Now, I'm leaning more to have these metadata items as properties of a flavor, rather than an image, since flavors are tied to arch via extra_specs{'cpu_arch'} and specified by the provider (not the users). Also, in a deployment with a large number of images, there would still probably be a small number of flavors.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-11-06 08:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-09 18:33:36.000000000', 'message': 'Added bare-metal documents.

Part 2 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

This documents describe how to install and configure bare-metal nova-compute
to support pxe and non-pxe(tilera) back-end machines.
The document includes what packages are needed for installation,
how to create bare-metal instance type, how to register bare-metal hosts and NIC,
and how to run instance.
Nova flags for the configuration of bare-metal nova-compute is described.

Change-Id: I6358e5ede094b4d887d15913b19f877169a0f99c
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
'}, {'created': '2012-08-13 18:26:00.000000000', 'message': 'Added bare-metal documents.

commit_message:
Add PXE sub-driver to baremetal driver.

This patch includes PXE / IPMI component for the baremetal driver.
The documents describe how to install and configure baremetal
nova-compute to support PXE back-end.

It includes the packages needed for installation, how to create
a bare-metal instance type, how to register bare-metal nodes and NIC,
and how to run an instance. Nova flags for the configuration of
bare-metal nova-compute are described.

Part 5 of 7: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

Change-Id: I6358e5ede094b4d887d15913b19f877169a0f99c
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
Co-authored-by: Devananda van der Veen <devananda.vdv@gmail.com>
DocImpact: adds bare-metal-pxe docs

When auto assigning floating IPs recreate the nw_info array
so that API calls to get instance details will immediately

Change-Id: Ib3b12e38e73c617390107bdb7547b55960a0ef2f

commit_message:
Recreate nw_info after auto assigning floating ip.

When auto assigning floating IPs recreate the nw_info array
so that API calls to get instance details will immediately
display the assigned floating IP info.

Fixes LP Bug #1053479 (for Essex).

Change-Id: Ib3b12e38e73c617390107bdb7547b55960a0ef2f

commit_message:
Add option to set MySQL engine.

Some operators have made some choices in their underlying MySQL architecture,
which our helpful assertion that they want to run on InnoDB breaks.

Add an option to nova which will allow such operators to tell us what they
want to run on. This is an advanced option and assumes that they know what
they are doing and defaults to the easy and sane choice of InnoDB.

Fixes bug 1069917.

Change-Id: I6556bf438be65344272883d254930e15f3ef0378

commit_message:
Move global service networking opts to new module

The my_ip, host and use_ipv6 options are used all over the codebase
and they're pretty well related to each other. Create a new netconf
module for them to live in.

There are now no options registered globally in nova.config!

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Ifde37839ae6f38e6bf99dff1e80b8e25fd68ed25

commit_message:
Move memcached_servers opt into common.memorycache

Add a factory function to nova.common.memorycache which consolidates
the code to choose between real or fake memcache. This then means that
memcached_servers is used in just one place and we can move the config
option there.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I67c191e0db58364eda4162b9e881606063509b9d

commit_message:
Move vpn_key_suffix into pipelib

Apart from one use in the EC2 API, vpn_key_suffix is only used in
pipelib.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: If90b9e77905161ea8d9263e8bae2c47ac5f79e91

commit_message:
convert add_nova_opt to iniset

Convert all calls to add_nova_opt to use
   iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT

Convert baremetal options to use
   iniset $NOVA_CONF baremetal

Change-Id: I03ce2149e1f3abc2feb40c156c50de7dabaf47a2

The baremetal hypervisor tracks references to instances which are deleted
asynchronously from the commit to the nova bm. As such, its a normal but rare
condition for a bare metal node to refer to a deleted (and even garbage
collected) nova instance. We should treat such instances are deleted rather
than erroring on any call through list_instances(), permitting starting
new instances and listing instances to work - fixing bug: 1096722.

Pathologically, the database may suffer permanent skew, which means we
need a way to fix it (and thats tracked as a separate bug).

commit_message:
Cope better with out of sync bm data.

The baremetal hypervisor tracks references to instances which are
deleted asynchronously from the commit to the nova bm. As such, its a
normal but rare condition for a bare metal node to refer to a deleted
(and even garbage collected) nova instance. We should treat such
instances are deleted rather than erroring on any call through
list_instances(), permitting starting new instances and listing
instances to work - fixing bug: 1096722.

Pathologically, the database may suffer permanent skew, which means we
need a way to fix it (and thats tracked as a separate bug).

Change-Id: Ic21ff66b1fc0ad64bb5feff26291873b96d20e4e

commit_message:
Verify size in addition to checksum of uploaded image

Fixes bug 1092584

Previously only the supplied checksum was verified against the actual
checksum calculated by the backend store, with the image being killed
on mismatch.

Now we also similarly verify the supplied image size, if provided.

Change-Id: I87fa3ff77715111f1095f3ebe64cd699776ec27e

commit_message:
Remove relative imports from NVP plugin

The majority of relative imports in the nvp plugin will be fixed in
blueprint nvp-api-client-loadbalance-request. This patch removes the
rest of them in and moves the vim tabstop line to the top of the
header file to be consistent with the rest of the files in quantum.
Fixes bug 1091596

Change-Id: I6c8299ca73ae5df75c87f302680908f863f81f02

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-21 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2012-10-22 09:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For volume capabilities to work across multiple drivers, they should be consistent and well-defined.  For example, we can do something like attributed in NFSv4:
1. create a set of "mandatory attributes" that every driver must support (e.g., total/used capacity, data protection level, etc.)
2. a set of "optional attributes" that not every driver supports, but will be consistent across drivers that do (e.g., thin provisioning support, compression support, dedup support, encryption support, etc.)
3. a set of "vendor-specific attributes" that define some proprietary capability; these capabilities will most likely be ignored by schedulers/filters included in OpenStack, but may be used by vendor-specific implementations.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-10-22 15:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-10-28 23:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Great job!  As I mentioned, it would be nice if capability keys were "standardized".  Maybe we can document required and recommended capability keys somewhere, and ensure that drivers use them properly in reviews?'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-21 15:48:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I left one implementation comment, but I didn't go much further with an in depth review because I have a fairly high level objection with this patch.

There is a significant amount of code copying going on here from nova.  The Oslo (openstack-common) project has been working hard to improve the situation.  I would really like to see some effort go into refactoring the filter scheduler as appropriate and sharing code via the oslo-incubator.

Some examples ...

 - the availability zone filter is a direct copy
 - filters/extra_specs_ops.py is a direct copy
 - filters/__init__.py was a direct copy, but has since been refactored and improved in nova, so this code isn't taking advantage of that work.  This is a good example why unmanaged copy/paste is a bad thing.

I think the best way to proceed is to start a thread on openstack-dev about how we can start sharing scheduler code between nova and cinder via the oslo-incubator."}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-11-21 16:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Will update soon.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-11-21 18:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-21 18:20:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Couple more notes on the implementation changes you just made.

To be clear, my objection about the lack of the use of oslo-inclubator is a part of the "-1" and I don't think this should go into Cinder until that is resolved.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 18:37:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-06 18:58:14.000000000', 'message': "Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are borrowed from Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_host_stats()/update_host_status() method of iSCSIDriver as an
example of how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- add extra_specs_ops.py to allow operations (string matching, value comparison
etc) on volume_type extra specs
- add least_cost.py and flags for cost functions (and weight) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing the cost of backends pass filters.
- add 'availability_zone', 'capability', 'capacity' filter.
- change scheduler driver flag to 'filter.FilterScheduler'.

Known issue:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. By default, volume nodes perioidically report status if
there its status/capabilities changed during the perioid, if (for any reason)
scheduler missed report (fanout) message from volume node, scheduler will ignore
the volume node. To simply work around this issue, this patch changes
'volume_force_update_capabilities' to true. More sophisticated way may be
add on table in DB to record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova
does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

Change-Id: I8b5305bce3b24bcc85365037356a8f36d0107133

"}, {'created': '2013-01-06 14:39:59.000000000', 'message': "Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are similar to the counterpart in Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_volume_stats() method of iSCSIDriver as an example to
demonstrate how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- port common filters/weights from oslo
- add capacity weigher (scheduler/weights/capacity.py) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing free capacity of the host. The default
behavior is to spread volumes across hosts; by changing the
'capacity_weight_multiplier' to negative number, volume placing behavior will
become stacking.
- add capacity filter which filters those hosts have insufficient storage space
to serve the request.
- add 'reserved_percentage' config option to indicate how much space is
reserved. Capacity reservation is needed when volume resize is enabled.
- change default scheduler to 'filter.FilterScheduler'.
- add 'publish_service_capabilities()' method to volume RPC API to allow
scheduler to have volume service report capabilities. This bumps volume RPC
API to version 1.1

The implication of this change to storage/backend driver developer:
- implementation of get_volume_stats() of the driver is now a *MUST*, filter
scheduler heavily relies on the status/capabilities reported by backend driver
to makeplacement decision.  To ensure Cinder works seamlessly on the storage
system, driver should at least report following capabilities/status:
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  Capability/Status   |      Description          |         Example
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
 'volume_backend_name'| back-end name, string     | 'Example_Storage_Backend'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'vendor_name'       | vendor name, string       | 'OpenStackCinder'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'driver_version'    | version, string           |  '1.0a'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_protocol'  | supported protocols,      | 'iSCSI', 'RBD', 'FC', 'NFS'
                      | string or list of strings | ['iSCSI', 'NFS', 'FC']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_media'     | supported storage medias, |  'SSD', 'SATA HDD', 'RAM'
                      | string or list of strings | ['SSD', 'SAS HDD']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'total_capacity_gb' | capacity in GB, integer   |  102400
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'free_capacity_gb'  | available capacity in GB, |  1000
                      | integer                   |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
'reserved_percentage' | reserved space in         |  0, 10
                      | percentage, integer       |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------

The implication of this change to Cinder administrator:
- the default setting for filter scheduler should work well with the benefits
of:
  * being able to fully utilize capacity of backends (driver now has to report
  actul total space and space utilization and scheduler uses these info) not
  limited by the 'max_gigabytes' config option any more;
  * being able to choose placement policy between spreading & stacking for
  volume creation (by modifying the 'capacity_weight_multiplier' in
  CapacityWeigher)
- with filter scheduler, Cinder is now able to utilize the advanced features/
capabilities provided by different storage back-ends via: defining different
volume types with proper extra_specs. Volume types can be considered as sets
of back-end capabilities requirement.
 For example, a volume type which has 'storage_media':'SSD' key/value pair
definition in its extra_spec can only be served by those back-ends who report
they support SSD as storage media. Another example is volume type has 'QoS'
requirement can only be served by back-ends support QoS.

Note:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. By default, volume nodes perioidically report status if
there its status/capabilities changed during the perioid, if (for any reason)
scheduler missed a few report (fanout) message from volume node, scheduler may
ignore the volume node. To simply work around this issue, this patch changes
'volume_force_update_capabilities' to true. More sophisticated way may be
add on table in DB to record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova
does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8b5305bce3b24bcc85365037356a8f36d0107133
