information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. By default, volume nodes perioidically report status if
there its status/capabilities changed during the perioid, if (for any reason)
scheduler missed a few report (fanout) message from volume node, scheduler may
ignore the volume node. To simply work around this issue, this patch changes
'volume_force_update_capabilities' to true. More sophisticated way may be
add on table in DB to record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova
does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8b5305bce3b24bcc85365037356a8f36d0107133
"}, {'created': '2013-01-06 14:57:50.000000000', 'message': "Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are similar to the counterpart in Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_volume_stats() method of iSCSIDriver as an example to
demonstrate how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- port common filters/weights from oslo
- add capacity weigher (scheduler/weights/capacity.py) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing free capacity of the host. The default
behavior is to spread volumes across hosts; by changing the
'capacity_weight_multiplier' to negative number, volume placing behavior will
become stacking.
- add capacity filter which filters those hosts have insufficient storage space
to serve the request.
- add 'reserved_percentage' config option to indicate how much space is
reserved. Capacity reservation is needed when volume resize is enabled.
- change default scheduler to 'filter.FilterScheduler'.
- add 'publish_service_capabilities()' method to volume RPC API to allow
scheduler to have volume service report capabilities. This bumps volume RPC
API to version 1.1

The implication of this change to storage/backend driver developer:
- implementation of get_volume_stats() of the driver is now a *MUST*, filter
scheduler heavily relies on the status/capabilities reported by backend driver
to makeplacement decision.  To ensure Cinder works seamlessly on the storage
system, driver should at least report following capabilities/status:
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  Capability/Status   |      Description          |         Example
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
 'volume_backend_name'| back-end name, string     | 'Example_Storage_Backend'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'vendor_name'       | vendor name, string       | 'OpenStackCinder'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'driver_version'    | version, string           |  '1.0a'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_protocol'  | supported protocols,      | 'iSCSI', 'RBD', 'FC', 'NFS'
                      | string or list of strings | ['iSCSI', 'NFS', 'FC']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_media'     | supported storage medias, |  'SSD', 'SATA HDD', 'RAM'
                      | string or list of strings | ['SSD', 'SAS HDD']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'total_capacity_gb' | capacity in GB, integer   |  102400
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'free_capacity_gb'  | available capacity in GB, |  1000
                      | integer                   |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
'reserved_percentage' | reserved space in         |  0, 10
                      | percentage, integer       |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------

The implication of this change to Cinder administrator:
- the default setting for filter scheduler should work well with the benefits
of:
  * being able to fully utilize capacity of backends (driver now has to report
  actul total space and space utilization and scheduler uses these info) not
  limited by the 'max_gigabytes' config option any more;
  * being able to choose placement policy between spreading & stacking for
  volume creation (by modifying the 'capacity_weight_multiplier' in
  CapacityWeigher)
- with filter scheduler, Cinder is now able to utilize the advanced features/
capabilities provided by different storage back-ends via: defining different
volume types with proper extra_specs. Volume types can be considered as sets
of back-end capabilities requirement.
 For example, a volume type which has 'storage_media':'SSD' key/value pair
definition in its extra_spec can only be served by those back-ends who report
they support SSD as storage media. Another example is volume type has 'QoS'
requirement can only be served by back-ends support QoS.

Note:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. By default, volume nodes perioidically report status if
there its status/capabilities changed during the perioid, if (for any reason)
scheduler missed a few report (fanout) message from volume node, scheduler may
ignore the volume node. To simply work around this issue, this patch changes
'volume_force_update_capabilities' to true. More sophisticated way may be
add on table in DB to record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova
does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8b5305bce3b24bcc85365037356a8f36d0107133

commit_message:
Implement filter scheduler

In order to do more sophisticated scheduling (e.g. schedule based on volume
type), filter scheduler is introduced. Several changes are made to make this
possible, some of them are similar to the counterpart in Nova:

- add HostState class to host_manager in order to store volume capabilities
- implement get_volume_stats() method of iSCSIDriver as an example to
demonstrate how volume backend driver reports capabilities as well as status
- add scheduler_options.py and 'scheduler_json_config_location' flag to be
allow loading json configuration file for scheduler at run time
- port common filters/weights from oslo
- add capacity weigher (scheduler/weights/capacity.py) for picking up
target volume backend by weighing free capacity of the host. The default
behavior is to spread volumes across hosts; by changing the
'capacity_weight_multiplier' to negative number, volume placing behavior will
become stacking.
- add capacity filter which filters those hosts have insufficient storage space
to serve the request.
- add 'reserved_percentage' config option to indicate how much space is
reserved. Capacity reservation is needed when volume resize is enabled.
- change default scheduler to 'filter.FilterScheduler'.
- add 'publish_service_capabilities()' method to volume RPC API to allow
scheduler to have volume service report capabilities. This bumps volume RPC
API to version 1.2
- remove 'volume_force_update_capabilities' config option, volume status will be
report to scheduler in every checking.

The implication of this change to storage/backend driver developer:
- implementation of get_volume_stats() of the driver is now a *MUST*, filter
scheduler heavily relies on the status/capabilities reported by backend driver
to makeplacement decision.  To ensure Cinder works seamlessly on the storage
system, driver should at least report following capabilities/status:
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  Capability/Status   |      Description          |         Example
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
 'volume_backend_name'| back-end name, string     | 'Example_Storage_Backend'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'vendor_name'       | vendor name, string       | 'OpenStackCinder'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'driver_version'    | version, string           |  '1.0a'
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'storage_protocol'  | supported protocols,      | 'iSCSI', 'RBD', 'FC', 'NFS'
                      | string or list of strings | ['iSCSI', 'NFS', 'FC']
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'total_capacity_gb' | capacity in GB, integer   |  102400
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
  'free_capacity_gb'  | available capacity in GB, |  1000
                      | integer                   |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------
'reserved_percentage' | reserved space in         |  0, 10
                      | percentage, integer       |
----------------------+---------------------------+---------------------------

The implication of this change to Cinder administrator:
- the default setting for filter scheduler should work well with the benefits
of:
  * being able to fully utilize capacity of backends (driver now has to report
  actul total space and space utilization and scheduler uses these info) not
  limited by the 'max_gigabytes' config option any more;
  * being able to choose placement policy between spreading & stacking for
  volume creation (by modifying the 'capacity_weight_multiplier' in
  CapacityWeigher)
- with filter scheduler, Cinder is now able to utilize the advanced features/
capabilities provided by different storage back-ends via: defining different
volume types with proper extra_specs. Volume types can be considered as sets
of back-end capabilities requirement.
 For example, a volume type which has 'storage_protocol':'FC' key/value pair
definition in its extra_spec can only be served by those back-ends who report
they support FiberChannel protocol. Another example is volume type has 'QoS'
requirement can only be served by back-ends support QoS.

Note/TODO:
* Currently scheduler makes its decision based on the status and capabilities
information reported by volume nodes, and these information is stored in memory
of scheduler process. More sophisticated way may be add on table in DB to
record status/capabilities of all volume nodes, like Nova does for compute nodes.

implement bp volume-type-scheduler

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8b5305bce3b24bcc85365037356a8f36d0107133

'}, {'account_id': 1782, 'date': '2013-01-06 11:29:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

There another option that i presented earlier. Adding new method get_instance_uuid to the driver api layer. I'm not sure about other drivers, but libvirt has instance uuid information."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-01-07 17:25:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I'm not sure about other drivers either, but that might not be a bad idea.  What you can do is add the method, then use something like:

    try:
        instance = instance_get_by_uuid(
            driver.get_instance_uuid(<blah>))
    except NotImplementedError:
        instance = instance_get(
            parse_instance_name(<blah>))

(representative pseudocode, of course)

That way, we have the nicer interface of get_instance_uuid(), with a fallback to the instance name parsing, and we can start making sure the virt layer has a way of getting the instance UUID.

That said, there may already be code somewhere in nova that determines the instance record corresponding to a given virtual machine.  IIRC, there used to be a periodic task in the compute manager that compares the VMs to the database; maybe that has some clues on how to accomplish what you need?"}, {'account_id': 1782, 'date': '2013-01-07 22:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2013-01-08 02:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Adds to manager init_host validation for instances location

While the compute was down the instances running on it could be
evacuated to another host. The method checks that instance host
identical to current host. Otherwise destroying it.

part of blueprint rebuild-for-ha

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic90df2b2887ee203e6d8261084e3f97773c5d81c
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Modify the v2 image tags to use domain model

A small patch to extend the work of porting v2 controllers to the new
domain model.

Part of implementing bp:glance-domain-logic-layer

Change-Id: I4fa4105f3862822a4bec869b3b72c5751160f9d3

commit_message:
Adding unit tests for auth.py

implements blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-reddwarfclient/+spec/reddwarfclient-unit-tests

Also changin the unit test library from unuttest2 to testtools per request of CI

Change-Id: I1b50cd4bf762c90b846ecb51db47f2afbfb6f175

fix int-tests running with out volume

Bug #1095929

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-04 18:00:36.000000000', 'message': 'Adds a new tenant-centric network extension

Implements: blueprint tenant-networks

Adds a new API extension that supports a more tenant-centric model for
interacting with isolated networks. Additionally, the patch renames the
existing networks extension as os-admin-networks to more fully fit the
self-described implementation. Two new novaclient extensions and a
novaclient change accompany this patch.

Change-Id: Ib90a65c0a92445f86e930fab88ab4495aefff7c7

Implements: blueprint tenant-networks

Adds a new API extension that supports a more tenant-centric model for
interacting with isolated networks. Additionally, the patch renames the
existing networks extension as os-admin-networks to more fully fit the
self-described implementation. Two new novaclient extensions and a

commit_message:
Adds a new tenant-centric network extension

Implements: blueprint tenant-networks

Adds a new API extension that supports a more tenant-centric model for
interacting with isolated networks. Additionally, the patch renames the
existing networks extension as os-admin-networks to more fully fit the
self-described implementation. Two new novaclient extensions and a
novaclient change accompany this patch.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib90a65c0a92445f86e930fab88ab4495aefff7c7

commit_message:
fix N402 for nova/tests

convert docstrings on test_ functions to comments to prevent the
function name from being masked by test infrastructure

convert the rest of the docstrings to end in punctuation as per N401

Change-Id: Ib400537c6f7feb30739207a627b5aac3a7eb165a

commit_message:
Fix N402 for nova/virt

Fix N402 errors (single line docstring should end in a period)
for nova/virt, part of a larger attempt to stop ignoring our own
hacking.py tests.

Change-Id: I523ce41bd2b38c73cf3fdb031101ccc0695f2488

[{'created': '2013-01-08 10:24:18.000000000', 'message': 'Move vpn_image_id to pipelib

Apart from checking whether a given image is the cloudpipe image, the
vpn_image_id option is only used within pipelib itself.

Add a is_vpn_image() helper method and move the option into pipelib.
Some rejiggering of how pipelib imports ec2 opts is required to avoid

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Ie984b2bb81681c24d3cee803082960083992a535

commit_message:
Move vpn_image_id to pipelib

Apart from checking whether a given image is the cloudpipe image, the
vpn_image_id option is only used within pipelib itself.

Add a is_vpn_image() helper method and move the option into pipelib.
Some rejiggering of how pipelib imports ec2 opts is required to avoid
circular imports.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Ie984b2bb81681c24d3cee803082960083992a535

commit_message:
Create a new guide for Basic Install

This commit is a collection of the following commits
related to the basic install guide in master branch.

- af7dd74 Create a new guide for Basic Install
- ae65b27 Fix small errors with several documents
- d084653 Add Network Controller + Improve Quantum Part
- 3bddf51 Adds post processing instruction to basic install pom.xml
- 939c50a Bug fixes for Basic Install reported in comments
- da78b4f Fix bug #1091859
- a1db24b Fix bug #1091988
- a20138c Fix Bug #1092424
- fac3c1e Brush up Quantum part of basic install guide

Change-Id: Ib37b0f1818ead064551fdd0884845fcaa6367ec8

commit_message:
Move enabled_apis option into nova.service

The enabled_apis option is only used in nova-api and nova-all but
there's no more obvious place to put it than nova.service. At least
this location is consistent, since we quite have a number of other
options related to the APIs in nova.service.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I86e200fa5ad91ac0b7ab6837cc61e5927b2ebeb7

commit_message:
Adds option to rebuild instance with existing disk

Evacuation of VM from a failed host for HA.
New api supports recreate/rebuild modes. With shared storage,
VM is recreated on the specified target from existing disk.
Otherwise, rebuild from original image is performed.

* new recreate, target host and on_shared_storage in rpcapi.rebuild
* change in manager.rebuild to rebuild instance using existing disk

part of blueprint rebuild-for-ha

DocImpact

Change-Id: I4d119eafc30da2779ad252259f88118ed0038cd1
Co-authored-by: Oshrit Feder <oshritf@il.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Log error on failure to load paste deploy app.

Fixes bug 1091294

Avoids possible silent failure of service launch when say a
dependency such as keystone is missing (but required by the
configured paste_deploy flavor).

Change-Id: I9a63d24bcf0a93277829d24073268210d2c063d3

[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-12-07 20:09:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Has there been any discussion about this anywhere?  If so, can you provide a link so that I can catch up?

This seems to overlap with the audit log.  What additional value does this provide?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-07 20:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/17715/1/check/gate-nova-merge/13582 : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-12-07 20:14:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Nevermind, I found the wiki page and such.  I'll read up before commenting further.  :)"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-07 20:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Cool :)

It started with https://etherpad.openstack.org/grizzly-error-handling-recovery from the last summit.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-12-11 17:00:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Good start.  This is going to be a nice addition!

(Wiki link: http://wiki.openstack.org/NovaInstanceActions)

I would like to be able to record multiple events per instance action.  Sometimes, there are multiple tracebacks that would be really great to record. (rescheduling)

You could have one table InstanceAction that maps to a high level action on the instance e.g. build/resize/etc.  Then a 2nd table, InstanceActionEvent with a FK on InstanceAction.   The idea would be to record multiple events (subactions?) per action.

Have you given thought to recording non-compute host related events?  If a request gets failed in the scheduler, the user will not see any results by querying the API extension.

Also, I am in favor of recording of non-user initiated events.  (e.g. auto resize confirmations)"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:40:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-12-12 15:40:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-12 16:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-12 16:36:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brian,

Working on a new db model, or two.

I definitely don't want to preclude non compute-host events but was deferring that due to the additional work I think it will require.  But a different db model like you suggested will be necessary for that.  That, coupled with the desire to keep db updates out of compute hosts means I'm now going to look at moving some calls up the stack sooner rather than later.

I'm also in favor of including non user initiated events, but I think they're going to need to be modified to look like user initiated events.  By that I mean they will need a request id, because that's the only information readily available to tie an event to the action it belongs to.  Unless I start passing the action id around which I would rather not do."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2012-12-19 15:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

commit_message:
New instance_actions and events table, model, and api

These tables will be a place to record actions taken on an instance, and
related underlying events.  This will provide a log of what has taken
place which can aid in debugging or just satisfy curiosity.  It will
also hold error information in the event that something exceptional
occurs during the action.  This is setting up the ability to report
error information without needing to set the VM to an ERROR state.

Blueprint instance-actions

Change-Id: I1f793abf0e4df0e4977850127fc41b4750ba2f4f

commit_message:
Allow nvp_api to load balance requests

The current version of the nvp_api client does not load balance
requests across multiple controllers. Instead, it just sends all the requests
to one controller and if there is a controller failure it will failover
to use another controller. This blueprint implements the ablility to
utilize all controllers at once.

blueprint nvp-api-client-loadbalance-request

Change-Id: I331be2a23ae360a95786152d5f116359f690d9f3

commit_message:
Fix database configuration of ryu-agent

Fixes bug #1097156

The database configuration was moved to the DB module.
This patch makes ryu-agent follow it.

Change-Id: Ib843132eb1a01769725dd89b1e1799c9d10790d3

commit_message:
Fix N402 for nova/api

Fix N402 errors (single line docstring should end in a period)
for nova/api, part of a larger attempt to stop ignoring our own
hacking.py tests.

Fix tests that look at docs in extensions

Change-Id: I89d89d1fcf37c4e7740c36375da4c751d1b621ed

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-09 13:15:12.000000000', 'message': 'fix msec format string

in the else case, which was triggered for devstack gate
the msec format string was incorrect, thus largely scrambling
the usefulness of logs. Fix this to make devstack readable.

commit_message:
fix msec format string

in the else case, which was triggered for devstack gate
the msec format string was incorrect, thus largely scrambling
the usefulness of logs. Fix this to make devstack readable.

Change-Id: I59d0e73932daf27dc1d718dfcf217fe2edf4d491

'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-03 18:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-07 13:46:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Do not merge

Ok, this seems to be attempting to handle the case where gettext.install() has already been called but with an incorrect translation domain

In the bug report, there is mention of the gettext.install() call in nova/__init__.py but I think we should just remove that call

Let me know if I'm missing something"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-01-08 03:18:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Mark, Thanks for your review!

Nova reference keystone as auth middleware, and use python*_client lib. Those auth middleware and client lib will log some messages. We install gettext in '__init__', then we can load translation domain for them when import them.

Server side code won't reference each other, we can
install gettext in 'bin/*' as you said. install gettext in '__init__' for all client side code. But If we install '__init__' will more easy, we won't modify all 'bin/*' file."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-09 08:07:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Again, nothing should run gettext.install() in an __init__.py file

The server binaries should run gettext.install()

Any code which is used as a library should use a _() method which is local to that module e.g.

  t = gettext.translation('keystone', fallback=True)

  def _(msg):
      return t.ugettext(msg)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-09 09:07:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I overstated that a little

No *library code* should run gettext.install() in its __init__.py files

I guess it's fine to do this for server side code if that code should never be imported by another project (and this is usually the case)

Looking through code some more, I only see this problem in quantumclient: https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-quantumclient/+bug/1097628

The keystone/__init__.py shouldn't be a problem for the auth_token middleware any more because the middleware has moved to keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-01-09 11:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

ok, I agree with you library shoudn't run 'gettext.install' in '__init__'. let me abandon this."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-01-09 11:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add custom gettext install for fixes translate domain overwrite

Fixes bug 974810

Add install function in openstack common utils. That function support
install gettext as fallback, then when one project reference another
project won't overwrite the translation domain.

All the openstack project should use this 'install' function in root
__init__.py file instead of use 'gettext.install'

Change-Id: Ie01455bda37945bb6ebfff6e2fd9b0ca6d056c50

commit_message:
How swift objects are layed out on filesystem

Implementation details on how Swift puts files on the filesystem.

Based on an email from John Dickisnon on the openstack mailing list.

(Also trims a lot of trailing whitespace from several lines in
this file).

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/19046

Change-Id: I835d00cfc381e40501baa2a05944a8e0be018844

commit_message:
Move common virt driver options to virt.driver

The default_ephemeral_format and use_cow_images options are used by a
number of virt drivers and nowhere else.

blueprint: scope-config-opts

commit_message:
Move api_class options to where they are used

The compute_api_class, network_api_class and volume_api_class options
are only used in their respective modules, so move them there.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Ib0497f46b44c4b3af7319550cc64c09d629ea362

commit_message:
Move manager options into nova.service

Move the compute_manager, console_manager, cert_manager, network_manager
and scheduler_manager options into nova.service.

Apart from the tests, these options are mostly just used in nova.service
so it makes sense for them to live there. Also, metadata_manager already
lives there.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I180859817b57c081b83d6a6f075a6ff76bb0ef6d

commit_message:
Move compute_topic into nova.compute.rpcapi

Even though the compute_topic opt is used outside nova.compute.rpcapi,
it makes sense for the RPC module to "own" the topic option.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I453951825481b9a5ba1865f6bf1223f7b1e25f98

Add access to update volume metadata.

This implements the cinderclient side of
blueprint: update-vol-metadata

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-08 21:50:25.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Support lookup of value using "group.key""

This reverts commit 525ac47.

There are already two ways to reference an option in a group:

  CONF.group.key
  CONF[group].key

Adding a third variant doesn't seem ideal. Also, for the specific case
of LazyPluggable in Nova, we can easily just pass an optional config
group name to the constructor.

Change-Id: I1a29a18d90e8af3ce2563bd1b3eeb64422140016
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Support lookup of value using "group.key""

This reverts commit 525ac47.

There are already two ways to reference an option in a group:

  CONF.group.key
  CONF[group].key

Adding a third variant doesn't seem ideal. Also, for the specific case
of LazyPluggable in Nova, we can easily just pass an optional config
group name to the constructor.

Change-Id: I1a29a18d90e8af3ce2563bd1b3eeb64422140016

Overall looks good to me.  I would appreciate it in the future if you responded to inline comments so that reviewers know what was taken care of and what you object to.  I still have a minor nitpick with the config options - there are generic config options available, and I'm not sure they should be redefined by each driver.  For example: hp3par_api_uri -> san_ip (may be a stretch) ; hp3par_username -> san_login ; hp3par_password -> san_password ; hp3par_debug -> debug.  Otherwise, looks OK to me!"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2012-12-24 03:21:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

confusion in the test and one nit. Good work!"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-12-27 05:21:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So other than the minor nits Mike pointed out overall this is nice work IMO.

As far as the debate on the flags, personally I'm not a fan of proliferating flags in the conf file, however for third party drivers I don't have a problem with it.  That being said, you seem to use both the standard san_ip and your api URL (one for SSH and the other for your client calls?).

Anyway, I'm ok with the custom flags if they're useful, but it might help alleviate some of the debate if you were to provide some comments in the code about the flags and their use?  Perhaps some docstrings in the requires section where you list all of the flags you need?

Also, you might want to think about things like MetaData or extensions (or even types/extra-specs) for some of the flags you have.  For the first rev the global is conf setting may be fine, but you might want to offer some more flexibility (like having different snapshots have different expirations etc).

Anyway, it's a big driver and I you put some really good work in to it, so thanks!!!"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2012-12-28 05:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

As Avishay, I would like to know why these need to be separate flags as well when existing ones would suffice.'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-02 17:56:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (2 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-18 22:48:48.000000000', 'message': "Provide HP 3PAR array iSCSI driver

The blueprint is here
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/hp3par-volume-driver

We have the driver broken into 2 files:
hp_3par_common.py and
hp_3par_iscsi.py

The reason we do this is because we have a fibre channel driver
that will be submitted shortly after this is committed.   The
fibre channel driver and the iscsi driver share a lot of the same
code that talks to the 3PAR array for provisioning.  So,
it made sense not to have duplicate code.  The fibre channel driver
will be dependent on the fibre channel support I am actively working
on for nova/cinder grizzly release.

The driver uses a 2 mechanisms to talk to the 3PAR array:
1) a python REST client (hp3parclient) that lives in the pypi
   repository here:
   http://pypi.python.org/pypi/hp3parclient

2) SSH.  We had to pull in some of the ssh code from the base san
   driver to help fix an issue with executing commands on the 3PAR
   array.  The 3PAR has the ability to turn on CSV output for command
   results, which makes this easier to parse.  Unfortunately, there
   is no way to turn CSV mode on permanently for all ssh requests.
   So, we have to turn on the CSV output for every single ssh command
   issued.

We use a dual mechianism because the REST API that ships with the 3.1.2
firmware doesn't support all of the capabilities a cinder driver needs
to export volumes.

When a newer version of the firmware comes out that supports host
management on the 3PAR array, then we will get rid of the SSH code.

Change-Id: I9826ba1a36e27a9be05457ee9236a491dbfd0713
"}, {'created': '2012-12-19 00:04:34.000000000', 'message': "Provide HP 3PAR array iSCSI driver

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/hp3par-volume-driver

that will be submitted shortly after this is committed.   The
fibre channel driver and the iscsi driver share a lot of the same
code that talks to the 3PAR array for provisioning.  So,
it made sense not to have duplicate code.  The fibre channel driver
will be dependent on the fibre channel support I am actively working
on for nova/cinder grizzly release.

The driver uses a 2 mechanisms to talk to the 3PAR array:
1) a python REST client (hp3parclient) that lives in the pypi
   repository here:
   http://pypi.python.org/pypi/hp3parclient

2) SSH.  We had to pull in some of the ssh code from the base san
   driver to help fix an issue with executing commands on the 3PAR
   array.  The 3PAR has the ability to turn on CSV output for command
   results, which makes this easier to parse.  Unfortunately, there
   is no way to turn CSV mode on permanently for all ssh requests.
   So, we have to turn on the CSV output for every single ssh command
   issued.

We use a dual mechianism because the REST API that ships with the 3.1.2
firmware doesn't support all of the capabilities a cinder driver needs
to export volumes.

When a newer version of the firmware comes out that supports host
management on the 3PAR array, then we will get rid of the SSH code.

Change-Id: I9826ba1a36e27a9be05457ee9236a491dbfd0713

commit_message:
Provide HP 3PAR array iSCSI driver

implements blueprint hp3par-volume-driver

We have the driver broken into 2 files:
hp_3par_common.py and
hp_3par_iscsi.py

The reason we do this is because we have a fibre channel driver
that will be submitted shortly after this is committed.   The
fibre channel driver and the iscsi driver share a lot of the same
code that talks to the 3PAR array for provisioning.  So,
it made sense not to have duplicate code.  The fibre channel driver
will be dependent on the fibre channel support I am actively working
on for nova/cinder grizzly release.

The driver uses a 2 mechanisms to talk to the 3PAR array:
1) a python REST client (hp3parclient) that lives in the pypi
   repository here:
   http://pypi.python.org/pypi/hp3parclient

2) SSH.  We had to pull in some of the ssh code from the base san
   driver to help fix an issue with executing commands on the 3PAR
   array.  The 3PAR has the ability to turn on CSV output for command
   results, which makes this easier to parse.  Unfortunately, there
   is no way to turn CSV mode on permanently for all ssh requests.
   So, we have to turn on the CSV output for every single ssh command
   issued.  Since we use ssh as well, we require the san_* options
   to be set.

We use a dual mechianism because the REST API that ships with the 3.1.2
firmware doesn't support all of the capabilities a cinder driver needs
to export volumes.

When a newer version of the firmware comes out that supports host
management on the 3PAR array, then we will get rid of the SSH code.

Change-Id: I9826ba1a36e27a9be05457ee9236a491dbfd0713

commit_message:
Move console_topic into nova.console.rpcapi

Even though the console_topic opt is used outside nova.console.rpcapi,
it makes sense for the RPC module to "own" the topic option.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: I0f00927ca1c0bba7b21315240165e83e7075ebb7

commit_message:
Move network_topic into nova.network.rpcapi

The network_topic opt is only used in nova.network.rpcapi and it makes
sense for the RPC module to "own" the topic option.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: Icd779f34df47ac6dd048b3e41995e872d8859872

commit_message:
Move cert_topic into nova.cert.rpcapi

The cert_topic opt is only used in nova.cert.rpcapi and it makes sense
for the RPC module to "own" the topic option.

blueprint: scope-config-opts
Change-Id: If3584b8e1984e0425d9f33133f9d291739b04d49

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-09 07:02:19.000000000', 'message': 'Pass X-Forwarded-For header to Nova

fixes bug 1097524

Add X-Forwarded-For header to the proxied Nova metadata request. Nova
needs this value to properly answer /latest/meta-data/local-ipv4
requests.

Change-Id: Icaec38b2ca7e06b50960deb7ab24ff1944a81f45
'}]
commit_message:
Pass X-Forwarded-For header to Nova

fixes bug 1097524

Add X-Forwarded-For header to the proxied Nova metadata request. Nova
needs this value to properly answer /latest/meta-data/local-ipv4
requests.

Change-Id: Icaec38b2ca7e06b50960deb7ab24ff1944a81f45

Do not run unstack.sh / rejoin-stack.sh as root

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-12-27 07:47:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add kernel_id and ramdisk_id in server information

Currently the kernel_id and ramdksi_id is not presented in response
for server information.

In block device mapping and euca invokation situation, because the
kernel_id and image_id is not always set in image property, that means
there is no method to get such information through novaclient.

Change-Id: I6439069d6a62b41c5f8d406812600f37de64f51e
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-12-27 08:52:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add kernel_id and ramdisk_id in server information

Currently the kernel_id and ramdksi_id is not presented in response
for server information.

In block device mapping and euca invokation situation, because the
kernel_id and image_id is not always set in image property, that means
there is no method to get such information through novaclient.

Change-Id: I6439069d6a62b41c5f8d406812600f37de64f51e
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add kernel_id and ramdisk_id in server information

Currently the kernel_id and ramdksi_id is not presented in response
for server information.

In block device mapping and euca invokation situation, because the
kernel_id and image_id is not always set in image property, that means
there is no method to get such information through novaclient.

Change-Id: I6439069d6a62b41c5f8d406812600f37de64f51e
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Collapse repeated code down in to nova/service.py

Each of the programs that use nova.service repeat a pattern of code, then
do service.Create. Because of that, it's gotten inconsistent. Instead,
we can put that into the Service class itself.

Change-Id: Id29c0063f5c5fefb90a0ffda086f9a7ee798993e

 bug 1015119
 bug 1039758

Change-Id: I6c738d85b3bd8789ee3597a413835fa9a11f0a6b
'}]
commit_message:
Refactoring API 2.0 content to create a single long dev guide.

The idea is to keep all the extension "dev guides" while also
building a long all-in-one PDF/HTML dev guide containing all calls.

Building off of 1.5.3. Also adjusted OS-KSEC2-admin.wadl to avoid
id collision with OS-KSADM method.

Now working through each "chapter" after OS-KSEC2 -- OS-KSS3 gives
errors at build time. See http://paste.openstack.org/show/27067/.
It's indicating that table elements are missing.

fixes:
 bug 961370
 bug 1015119
 bug 1039758

Change-Id: I6c738d85b3bd8789ee3597a413835fa9a11f0a6b

commit_message:
use rootwrap to restrict the iproute(2) commands

fixes bug 1081795

Previously, the rootwrap filters allowed all iproute subcommands
including exec.  This patch adds a filter tailored for the iproute utils
that prohibits exec.

Change-Id: Ief810ff079c17256f6039c60bb32ec1263f59891

Without more explanation, this looks to me like it might break stuff - it looks like rather than re-generating the versioninfo file, we re-use any versioninfo that happens to be lying around in my source tree. Surely re-using a stale versioninfo is bad?

Another thing that's weird - the _newer_version() method means we basically ignore the date in any versioninfo file we read - e.g. if I generate a tarball today and install it tomorrow, it will use tomorrow's date in the version?

Also, just noticed - the deferred_version_string() thing looks broken:

commit_message:
Swap the order of preference around versioninfo.

The current preference order makes life VERY hard for doing things like
git-buildpackage, and has next to no benefit.

Change-Id: Ib067596c594af6dd6234a0c0f42dcad4233ea636

It might be safer (more repeatable) to move the version metadata file into the branch with the source, so we could just read from a local file instead of messing with git.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-11-21 13:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Doug: I think that was considered but dropped, Jim and Monty might remember why.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2012-11-21 23:25:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do we use "git archive" to create our tarballs?
If so you can recover the sha and thus the version.

Looks like not (this doesn't return the commit-id):
zcat ~/Downloads/ceilometer-2013.1~g1~20121121.376.tar.gz | git get-tar-commit-id

But if we did then we would just need to do:
git describe $(result_of_above_command)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-11-22 08:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No, we are using "python setup.py sdist", which makes it go through setup.py and MANIFEST.in to decide which files to actually include (git archive would iiuc include all the tree). Monty is the specialist of this code, which went through several iterations.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-11-22 10:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm fine with the env-var override. There are a BUNCH of requirements here (ttx and I should probably write up a page on it) and not to shut anyone down (like Doug's perfectly sensible suggestion) but it's one of those areas where the first 12 sensible things have all been tried.

That being said, I'm TOTALLY in favor of having an in-depth discussion with people about better ways to handle things... as long as no one starts any sentences with "it's easy, just do ... " :)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-22 12:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

If Monty and Thierry are ok with the change, I am too. I'll wait for that requirements doc before suggesting any other easy fixes. ;)"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-22 14:44:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm fine with the change but, while we're at it, let's get more info than just "that doesn't mean every other commands based on git should work"

Are your git repositories missing tags so 'git tag --contains HEAD' doesn't work?

Are you sure there's no logic we can add here to help your use case?

How do other projects you build from git handle this? Do they have the version info in the git repo?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-22 14:55:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Mark: the problem is that first command this code tries is 'git fetch' and you can imagine easily how it fails.

I've tested this patch and it seems to be enough for now to build, since the main problem was in get_pre_version.

But now that you talk about it, I see a similar pattern in get_post_version(), would like me to modify that one too?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-22 15:01:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If the issue is with 'git fetch', would a simple LOCAL_ONLY=1 env var help? i.e. a way to disable network access during building"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-22 15:30:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1057560

This patch doesn't address that issue, but it sounds like a patch to address it might fix things for Debian packagers too?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-22 15:33:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, this is totally related to #1057560 indeed.

A way to disable network access would also be good. On the other hand, a way to entirely disable git usage would be great too since it would avoid adding a build-depends on git. Though it's probably still acceptable."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-27 17:00:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there anything still blocking or could I get my approval? ;-)'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-11-29 09:32:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So, I don't have a problem with the patch - but jeblair and I had a great conversation about a more fundamental fix that I need to write up a part of for agreement. There's also a logic swap I would like to put in here that I believe would make the need for this go away..."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-12-03 07:26:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Monty - would be great to see that writeup

Presumably Ib067596c594af6dd6234a0c0f42dcad4233ea636 is the logic swap that "makes the need for this go away" ?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-20 17:12:05.000000000', 'message': "setup: allow version override

Debian packagers use git to do their packaging, so .git exists, but that
doesn't mean every other commands based on git should work. So let's allow
them to set which version this is via an environment variable.

Change-Id: Ibc3c7cea2061d2d3d855e1d5827cc4e6d258e65d
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}]
commit_message:
setup: allow version override

Debian packagers use git to do their packaging, so .git exists, but that
doesn't mean every other commands based on git should work. So let's allow
them to set which version this is via an environment variable.

Change-Id: Ibc3c7cea2061d2d3d855e1d5827cc4e6d258e65d
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Ensure the check for Glance's durable queues filters for glance

There are legit durable queues that may be returned by the
check for list_queues | grep true. We need to filter for just
the glance queues to prevent unintended consequences for other
projects

Change-Id: Ia284ced949e8304aa298a6724de4eaaa4bfb5d44

'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2012-11-26 13:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-11-26 14:46:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Personally, I use stderr as a way to print things to the screen while debugging a test, so I don't really want that to be merged in with everything else.

Further, the nosetests.log is really only there so that the script can determine if no tests were run as a result of an error. If you want to capture all of the output merged together, you can do:

./run_tests.sh 2>&1 | tee my.log

and get the desired result.

What test or situation are you running into where output makes it to stderr?

I'm not supremely opposed to this, but I'm -1 because I think it makes it harder to use stderr for debugging purposes. However, someone else feel free to override me."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2012-11-26 15:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Dan, I don't think this patch would affect your usecase. Anything that is printed to stderr from the tests will still be shown. In addition to that, it will be logged. Unless you wanted to still keep the streams separated in the output of run_tests.sh?

I don't think this should affect debugging tests, since in that case I expect you're running just `./run_tests.sh tests.only.the.interesting:Module.test_function`. The output would still be shown.

This change has two use cases for me really: 1. some versions / configurations of nosetest actually outputs the "Ran xxx tests" line to stderr ; 2. errors in nosetests itself don't get saved in the log file and you have to capture them separately.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-11-26 15:42:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Right, I understand. However, stderr is unbuffered and stuffing it through tee will cause it to be. I'm just not a fan of that approach, but I'm only -1 here so someone else can override it if they want.

Again, what is the common case for catching stderr stuff in the log? I think that anything that gets run from a test or other module should be LOG'd appropriately, and tests in the tree shouldn't be printing to stderr. So, what's the need for this?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-26 16:59:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM

The problem is, the tests *do* write to stderr.  I notice it every time I run the test suite, but never sat down to figure out why and what exactly was going on (didn't figure out it was stderr until I saw this patch, in fact).  Of course, the ultimate fix is to ensure that stderr is redirected within nose itself, rather than just run_tests.sh (in fact, this won't fix the problem I observe, since I usually use tox to run the test suite instead of ./run_tests.sh)."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-11-26 17:10:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Kevin,

Where is that? I don't see any examples in nova/tests nor do I recall seeing stderr output in normal runs..."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-11-26 17:28:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I see random output during every test run I do.  Like I say, I've not sat down and tried to figure out the how and why; all I can say is, I see it."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-26 21:19:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is a duplicate of: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15606/"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:42:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Just so no one is confused and merges by accident, it really is duplicate work'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

commit_message:
Save complete nosetests output.

Some cases of nosetests output can go to stderr which would not be
saved. Redirect stderr to stdout to handle even the extreme cases.

Change-Id: Iea11f07f18b908a3c805612d283e0b6157df0af8

subject: Proof of Concept: prevent sqlalchemy object leaks
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2889, 'name': 'Aeva Black', 'email': 'aeva.online@gmail.com', 'username': 'tenbrae'}, {'_account_id': 5511, 'name': 'Nikola Dipanov', 'email': 'ndipanov@redhat.com', 'username': 'ndipanov'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-05 21:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Submitting this code as a Proof of Concept'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-05 21:49:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Results from test: https://etherpad.openstack.org/sqlalchemy-leaks'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-08 04:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

could we use a similar decorator magic in sqlalchemy/api.py to do the check and just call dict(obj.iteritems()) to do the conversion for us?'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-13 02:05:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Vishy, using decorator magic to change the return values is not enough.  Many times we do something like instance_ref.name where instance_ref is a sqlalchemy object.   and if we change the return value to a dict you get:

AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'name'"}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2012-11-13 09:30:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Joe, so we need to actually make sure that the returned value responds to dotted lookups as well as __getitem__ lookups. This is fuctionality can be obtained by inheriting from sqlachemy.models.NovaBase (but is coupled with sqlalchemy).

So maybe the decorator should check if the return value isinstance of NovaBase, but maybe we should also have a more generalized way of allowing both dotted and dict lookups not related to the actual DB implementation.

This I think might be a better way to go then counting these things in the generalized db driver that should not know about them in any way.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-13 19:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ndipanov,

This code currently is just to highlight all the sqlachemy abstraction leaks. 

Unless there is an elegant way to support dotted lookups without using sqlalchemy objects, I will go down the path of  converting all dotted lookups to dict lookups.

long term, I do not want to be using a decorator that is applied via introspection  to convert return values.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-15 00:22:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joe: there is special handling for .name to convert it to 'name' when we convert to a primitive for rpc. We can use the same handling if using decorator magic, we just have to make sure that we use instance['name'] instead of instance.name (which we should be doing anyway)."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-22 01:46:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-11-22 01:46:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Work in Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-22 02:14:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

nova.db.api should not be returning sqlalchemy objects.
This code inspects all return values in nova.db.api and checks for
sqlalchemy objects.

The current implementation is designed to record all encapsulation
violations to a text file: sqlalchemy-leaks.txt

Change-Id: I0c380d593d7431ff6c8c0c91d9a17ebf9bc60b32
'}, {'created': '2012-11-22 01:46:02.000000000', 'message': 'Proof of Concept: prevent sqlalchemy object leaks

nova.db.api should not be returning sqlalchemy objects.

This code inspects all return values in nova.db.api and checks for
sqlalchemy objects.

inspectReturns - record all encapsulation violations in sqlalchemy-leaks.txt
fixReturns - convert sqlalchemy objects to a dictionary that is
accessible via attributes

Change-Id: I0c380d593d7431ff6c8c0c91d9a17ebf9bc60b32
'}]
commit_message:
Proof of Concept: prevent sqlalchemy object leaks

nova.db.api should not be returning sqlalchemy objects.

This code inspects all return values in nova.db.api and checks for
sqlalchemy objects.

inspectReturns - record all encapsulation violations in sqlalchemy-leaks.txt
fixReturns - convert sqlalchemy objects to a dictionary that is
accessible via attributes

Change-Id: I0c380d593d7431ff6c8c0c91d9a17ebf9bc60b32

subject: Get *BIN_DIR after repo is cloned
messages:
[{'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-10 17:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I might be missing something, but I think we can simplify this further - see inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-12-10 18:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

In https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/commit/9fbeeddc3b6ea28c06d5468b0bc28966d4fbc6ce Monty moved to support using the entry-points location for binaries.  Is there any reason to continue to support the project dir location at all?'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-10 18:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@dean: i can't say I know what "console entrypoints" means/are, but if you look at the bug mentioned, devstack is not finding any binaries, so it does not appear to be populating /usr/local/bin with scripts. Only the ones in the projects dir exist'}, {'account_id': 5241, 'date': '2012-12-11 09:15:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Dean: Ok, but then the commit you posted breaks first run in Fedora, because all scripts are installed to /usr/bin instead of /usr/local/bin:
...
Installing nova-all script to /usr/bin
Installing nova-api script to /usr/bin
Installing nova-api-ec2 script to /usr/bin
Installing nova-api-metadata script to /usr/bin
...

And stack.sh is trying to run those scripts from *BIN_DIR which defaults to /usr/local/bin/ 

So the other way we could fix this is:
a) do some is_fedora testing and default to /usr/bin/ instead in case of Fedora
b) tell setuptools to install scripts to /usr/local/bin/ in setup_develop function: python setup.py develop --script-dir=$2

Any other ideas?'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-12-11 16:14:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, it looks the the real issue here is that Ubuntu setuptools writes to /usr/local/bin and Fedora writes to /usr/bin.  I don't know which one is "right" but my SA-gut tells me that non-system tools writing to /usr/bin is wrong; however that discussion belongs not here.

It seems to me the fix you seek is just setting *_BIN_DIR to the setuptools dest properly.  The question about still needing to support the project bin dir remains but I suspect the answer there is 'no'.

If possible I would like setting the dir variable to remain with the other defaults so it can be picked up by other projects without actually running the config function.  Currently only Nova has the potential for this being a problem in stack.sh but that is not the only script that uses the lib/* files now.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

This type of functionality is what we intend to go into the nova-conductor service.  :-)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-04 18:42:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Except the nova-conductor service is happening at a different level, correct? 

From what I can tell from nova-conductor it hasn't gotten past.

	"""Handles database requests from other nova services"""

There are 2 different ways of doing this, this one is top-down, the nova-conductor seems to be bottom-up and focused on db-rpc stuff which this isn't concerned with (ie solving no-db-compute). They are 2 different (although similar goals) where this one will focus on creating a state-machine that gets a api request and does all the steps necessary to complete said request (focusing on compute requests to start). It also has the benefit of being able to remove all db-calls, but in a different manner (by orchestrating all the sql calls into its layer).

From your blog:

The methods exposed by nova-conductor will initially be relatively simple methods used by nova-compute to offload its database operations. Places where nova-compute previously did database access will now be talking to nova-conductor.

And yes your blog states that it will get farther than that someday. I just am going to make that someday happen a lot earlier since I believe its more important than removing db calls (ie better to have your states orchestrated  and rolled back correctly than disconnecting your db from a compute node).'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:14:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

It's fine if you want to work on those types of changes, I just think it needs to be in the nova-conductor service, not a new one."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:16:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think we need yet another nova-foo service for this. If you have orchestration functionality to add, please add it to conductor."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-04 19:30:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, i'll delete the new binary. 

I'm really focused on making the manager correct, if others want to use the manager in nova-conductor, feel free, but lets not get to excited over small details like that. There is alot of work to be done, and to early for said complaints ;-)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-04 23:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-12-04 23:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-04 23:34:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Begin adding a simple orchestration layer.

The goal of this layer is to be able to provide a high
level api reception point for which requests for resources
(initially compute resources) will channel through. It will
handle the complex set of transitions (and unraveling) needed
on errors and state transitions so that the components provisioning
and consuming those resources do not have to be complicated by
such knowledge.

This layer will initially be targeted at working this model
into the compute 'create' call where it can be used to show
others of how such a model is better than what exists currently.

Blueprint instance-create-state-machine

See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/RepairingOwnership
See also: http://wiki.openstack.org/SchedulingSplitout (a dependent)

Change-Id: I2cfbd834623153820141e99abe5f1350165af9f2

subject: Add confirmation before swift delete --all.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-21 16:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/16650/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-merge/139 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16650/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-docs/88 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16650/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-pep8/137 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16650/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python26/136 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/16650/1/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python27/136 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2012-11-21 17:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-26 19:23:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This will break every script that uses "delete --all".'}, {'account_id': 6215, 'date': '2012-11-26 20:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I know, that it will break it, but it does make sense, that you are going to be asked, if you want to delete everything. It is a major change and shouldn't be released till a major release. It doesn't make any sense imo, if someone have to give another parameter to be asked. To be honest, would you add a "interactive" parameter, to be asked if you really want this? I'll guess not. But it makes sense, if that is the default and if you don't want to be asked (e.g. in scripts) you have to give another parameter (like here "-n", "--non-interactive").'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-29 20:08:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I don't think it's worth the breakage. To me, "swift delete --all" is like "rm -f" or "fsck -y": you're saying "do it and damn the consequences". It's not like a simple "swift delete" defaults to deleting everything.

This is just my opinion, though, so I'll leave my vote at -1. If enough other reviewers think it's a good idea to merge this, I'm fine with being outvoted.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-12-10 06:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Sam, IMHO swift CLI is no mean to be interactive expecting a PTY and as said by Sam --all is already an acknowledgement by the user to delete everything"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

I've never been entirely certain what the original rationale for using REBOOT_HARD instead of REBOOT_SOFT was (the decision predates my involvement in the project).

Ideally we would provide both options, but the question is how to convey those to the user meaningfully... maybe "Reboot" vs. "Restart", or "Reboot (OS)" vs. "Reboot (Power)".

I don't *think* I want to arbitrarily change this without providing both options, though, since it would be altering an expected existing behavior. Copying the action and providing both would be better.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2012-12-11 11:32:37.000000000', 'message': "Reboot instance in the soft mode by default.

Fix bug 1088859

Currently, horizon reboots instance via the 'HARD' mode which
stops instance by destroying it. This would trigger some unusual
behavior for instance(such as reboots twice due to fsck). Nova has
provided scheme to reboot instance in the 'SOFT' mode, which is
more elegant. Thus it is reasonable for us to switch to the 'SOFT'
mode by default.

Change-Id: I81792966e37e3581d098ddc663e679e508019a7a
"}, {'created': '2012-12-11 12:11:08.000000000', 'message': "Reboot instance in the soft mode by default.

Currently, horizon reboots instance via the 'HARD' mode which
stops instance by destroying it. This would trigger some unusual
behavior for instance(such as reboots twice due to fsck). Nova has
provided scheme to reboot instance in the 'SOFT' mode, which is
more elegant. Thus it is reasonable for us to switch to the 'SOFT'
mode by default.

Change-Id: I81792966e37e3581d098ddc663e679e508019a7a
"}]
commit_message:
Reboot instance in the soft mode by default.

Fix bug 1088859

Currently, horizon reboots instance via the 'HARD' mode which
stops instance by destroying it. This would trigger some unusual
behavior for instance(such as reboots twice due to fsck). Nova has
provided scheme to reboot instance in the 'SOFT' mode, which is
more elegant. Thus it is reasonable for us to switch to the 'SOFT'
mode by default.

Change-Id: I81792966e37e3581d098ddc663e679e508019a7a

Add ISCSI_HELPER as a configurable parameter, which is set to tgtadm by default.

Bug 1072982.

I like the general idea of separating the request validation from the controller, but have some comments:

1) Patch is fairly big.  If you break it up into multiple commits, gerritt will automatically create multiple previews with proper dependencies. (git-review -R)

2) Using the word 'parser' feels wrong.  This is more of a demarshalling function than any actual parsing.

3) Code location - Feels a little off.  For example, code specific to demarshalling server-related requests should continue to live under nova/api/openstack/compute/servers, whereas the common plumbing could go under nova/api.  I don't see the need for a new top level directory under nova."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-06 20:30:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-06 02:38:59.000000000', 'message': 'Begin run_instance cleanup!

On the way to orchestration, here we come!
But first lets not do distributed partial validation in so many places!

Change-Id: Iea8bda659e78b406d75936483de5b9599575f852
'}, {'created': '2012-11-14 02:55:11.000000000', 'message': 'Begin run_instance cleanup!

On the way to orchestration, here we come!
But first lets not do distributed partial validation in so many places!

Change-Id: Iea8bda659e78b406d75936483de5b9599575f852
'}, {'created': '2012-12-01 02:15:11.000000000', 'message': "Move to layer that parses and verifies request components.

Instead of having a servers controller that has parsing and
validation of the input wsgi request objects it is useful to
start to centralize this code into a API controller and then
hand-off the objects recieved to a set of request parsers
whose job is to validate the input request (using shared
validation methods) and form objects for the API controller
to use.

This commit does this for the following methods:

1. 'index', 'detail' via a common 'SearchOptionsParser'
2. 'create' via a 'CreateParser'
3. 'update' via a 'UpdateParser'
4. 'changePassword' via a 'ChangePasswordParser'
5. 'resize' via a 'ResizeParser'
6. 'rebuild' via a 'RebuildParser'

Change-Id: Iea8bda659e78b406d75936483de5b9599575f852
"}, {'created': '2012-12-03 22:38:05.000000000', 'message': "Move to layer that parses and verifies request components.

Instead of having a servers controller that has parsing and
validation of the input wsgi request objects it is useful to
start to centralize this code into a API controller and then
hand-off the objects recieved to a set of request parsers
whose job is to validate the input request (using shared
validation methods) and form objects for the API controller
to use.

This commit does this for the following methods:

1. 'index', 'detail' via a common 'SearchOptionsParser'
2. 'create' via a 'CreateParser'
3. 'update' via a 'UpdateParser'
4. 'changePassword' via a 'ChangePasswordParser'
5. 'resize' via a 'ResizeParser'
6. 'rebuild' via a 'RebuildParser'

Change-Id: Iea8bda659e78b406d75936483de5b9599575f852

commit_message:
Move to layer that unmarshals and verifies request components.

Instead of having a servers controller that has parsing and
validation of the input wsgi request objects it is useful to
start to centralize this code into a API controller and then
hand-off the objects recieved to a set of request marshaling objects
whose sole job is to validate the input request (using shared
validation methods) and form objects for the API controller
to use.

This commit does this for the following methods:

1. 'index', 'detail' via a common 'SearchUnmarshaller'
2. 'create' via a 'CreateUnmarshaller'
3. 'update' via a 'UpdateUnmarshaller'
4. 'changePassword' via a 'ChangePasswordUnmarshaller'
5. 'resize' via a 'ResizeUnmarshaller'
6. 'rebuild' via a 'RebuildUnmarshaller'

Change-Id: Iea8bda659e78b406d75936483de5b9599575f852

commit_message:
XenAPI: fix oneiric issue: hgtools

Fixes bug 1078307

If ubuntu oneiric is used for devstack, the install failed, due to a
missing dependency, hgtools. This workaround installs hgtools, so
devstack won't fail.

Change-Id: Id65fcaa086b66d0a38613f5df7b59074c84a7a5c

- http://logs.openstack.org/18071/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/4397 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-12-17 10:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I found the commit message a little unclear. Both 'if there was enough free space' and 'if the volume group was large enough' both sound like the same check.

Looking at the code, it appears the problem being addressed is around sparse images. With sparse images we pre-allocate only 64 MB of volume space. The existing code was only checking if the volume group could hold this initial '64MB' sparse allocation. The new check validates the non-sparse image size.

This new check raises an interesting question about how Nova deals with sparse images though. Your change is only dealing with one small edge case.

Say you have a volume group with 10 GB free space. If you want to create an sparse image with 11 GB size, previously this would be allowed, but now your check will deny it. Conversely if you want to create a sparse image 9 GB in size, your check will allow it. And it will allow you to create another 9 GB image, and another, and another, and another.

So you're preventing creating a sparse image that exceeds the free size, but allowing creation of (free size / 64 MB) * sparse images that are each less than the free size.

Obviously when using sparse images, someone / something, needs to be monitoring the LVM volume group free space to increase the allocation at some point. I'm not convinced that Nova should be validating the free space against the logical image size, as you propose, because the check is somewhat arbitrary & even meaningless if the free space is slightly higher than the image size.

If we want to check space related to the logical image size, then I think it could be more beneficial to check against a free space "lower bound". eg forbid creating a new image, if the current free space is less than 10 GB.

Or actually should we have an "overcommit ratio" for disk space, where we allow creation of sparse images that are no more than 1.5 x the physical size.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-09 06:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Refactor lvm image creation

When creating an lvm image we were checking to see
if there was enough free space in the volume group
in order to create an iamge. However we were not checking
to see if volume group was large enough to contain
an image as well.

Adds a new function called volume_group_size which
checks the volume_group size.

Also raises an error if lvm image creation fails.

Change-Id: Ideb9ff6f96f0db88d88d0100f0f1a9c693f70a52
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add a API for deleting a tenant by its name (bug 1087234)

API Definition:

    Verb: DELETE URI: v2.0/tenants?name=string Description: Delete a tenant by its name

    Normal Response Code(s): 204

    Error Response Code(s): identityFault (400, 500, ...), badRequest (400), unauthorized (401), forbidden (403), badMethod (405), overLimit (413), serviceUnavailable (503), itemNotFound (404)

    This call deletes a tenant.

    Request Parameters: X-Auth-Token(HEAD, string) name(Query, string)

Change-Id: I05032da1d45c0950abe473b72e9645d40e09ac76
